					<div id="mw-content-text" class="mw-body-content"><div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" lang="en" dir="ltr"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party since 2012</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1236090951">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}@media print{body.ns-0 .mw-parser-output .hatnote{display:none!important}}</style><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">In this <a href="/wiki/Chinese_name" title="Chinese name">Chinese name</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_surname" title="Chinese surname">family name</a> is <i> <a href="/wiki/Xi_(surname)" title="Xi (surname)">Xí</a> (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh-Hans" style="font-style: normal;">习</span></span>)</i>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">

</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1289430074">.mw-parser-output .infobox-subbox{padding:0;border:none;margin:-3px;width:auto;min-width:100%;font-size:100%;clear:none;float:none;background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .infobox-3cols-child{margin:auto}.mw-parser-output .infobox .navbar{font-size:100%}@media screen{html.skin-theme-clientpref-night .mw-parser-output .infobox-full-data:not(.notheme)>div:not(.notheme)[style]{background:#1f1f23!important;color:#f8f9fa}}@media screen and (prefers-color-scheme:dark){html.skin-theme-clientpref-os .mw-parser-output .infobox-full-data:not(.notheme) div:not(.notheme){background:#1f1f23!important;color:#f8f9fa}}@media(min-width:640px){body.skin--responsive .mw-parser-output .infobox-table{display:table!important}body.skin--responsive .mw-parser-output .infobox-table>caption{display:table-caption!important}body.skin--responsive .mw-parser-output .infobox-table>tbody{display:table-row-group}body.skin--responsive .mw-parser-output .infobox-table th,body.skin--responsive .mw-parser-output .infobox-table td{padding-left:inherit;padding-right:inherit}}</style><table class="infobox vcard"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" class="infobox-above" style="font-size: 100%;"><div class="fn" style="font-size:125%;">Xi Jinping</div></th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" class="infobox-subheader" style="font-size:125%; <div class="marriage-display-ws"><div style="display:inline-block;line-height:normal;margin-top:1px;white-space:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Ke_Lingling" title="Ke Lingling">Ke Lingling</a></div>

</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Relatives</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Qi_Qiaoqiao" title="Qi Qiaoqiao">Qi Qiaoqiao</a> (sister)</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Residence</th><td class="infobox-data label"><a href="/wiki/Zhongnanhai" title="Zhongnanhai">Zhongnanhai</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Education</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Tsinghua_University" title="Tsinghua University">Tsinghua University</a> (<a href="/wiki/B._S." class="mw-redirect" title="B. advisor">Doctoral advisor</a></th><td class="infobox-data">Liu Meixun (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh">刘美珣</span></span>)</td></tr><tr style="display:none"><td colspan="2">
</td></tr><tr style="display:none"><td colspan="2">
</td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" class="infobox-full-data"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1235681985">.mw-parser-output .side-box{margin:4px 0;box-sizing:border-box;border:1px solid #aaa;font-size:88%;line-height:1.25em;background-color:var(--background-color-interactive-subtle,#f8f9fa);display:flow-root}.mw-parser-output .side-box-abovebelow,.mw-parser-output .side-box-text{padding:0.25em 0.9em}.mw-parser-output .side-box-image{padding:2px 0 2px 0.9em;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .side-box-imageright{padding:2px 0.9em 2px 0;text-align:center}@media(min-width:500px){.mw-parser-output .side-box-flex{display:flex;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .side-box-text{flex:1;min-width:0}}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .side-box{width:238px}.mw-parser-output .side-box-right{clear:right;float:right;margin-left:1em}.mw-parser-output .side-box-left{margin-right:1em}}</style><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1290232777">.mw-parser-output .listen .side-box-text{line-height:1.1em}.mw-parser-output .listen-plain{border:none;background:transparent}.mw-parser-output .listen-embedded{width:100%;margin:0;border-width:1px 0 0 0;background:transparent}.mw-parser-output .listen-header{padding:2px}.mw-parser-output .listen-embedded .listen-header{padding:2px 0}.mw-parser-output .listen-file-header{padding:4px 0}.mw-parser-output .listen .description{padding-top:2px}.mw-parser-output .listen .mw-tmh-player{max-width:100%}@media(max-width:719px){.mw-parser-output .listen{clear:both}}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .listen:not(.listen-noimage){width:320px}.mw-parser-output .listen-left{overflow:visible;float:left}.mw-parser-output .listen-center{float:none;margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto}}</style><div class="side-box side-box-left listen noprint listen-embedded listen-noimage listen-center"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1126788409" />

<div class="side-box-text plainlist"><div class="haudio">
<div class="listen-file-header"><a href="/wiki/File:Xi%27s_voice_2021.ogg" title="File:Xi&#39;s voice 2021.ogg">Xi Jinping's voice</a></div>
<div><span typeof="mw:File"><span><audio id="mwe_player_0" controls="" preload="none" data-mw-tmh="" class="mw-file-element" width="215" style="width:215px;" data-durationhint="88" data-mwtitle="Xi&#39;s_voice_2021.ogg" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons"><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a2/Xi%27s_voice_2021.ogg" type="audio/ogg; codecs=&quot;vorbis&quot;" data-width="0" data-height="0" /><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a2/Xi%27s_voice_2021.ogg/Xi%27s_voice_2021.ogg.mp3" type="audio/mpeg" data-transcodekey="mp3" data-width="0" data-height="0" /><track src="https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;title=File%3AXi%27s_voice_2021.ogg&amp;lang=en&amp;trackformat=vtt&amp;origin=%2A" kind="subtitles" type="text/vtt" srclang="en" label="English ‪(en)‬" data-dir="ltr" /><track src="https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;title=File%3AXi%27s_voice_2021.ogg&amp;lang=zh-hans&amp;trackformat=vtt&amp;origin=%2A" kind="subtitles" type="text/vtt" srclang="zh-Hans" label="中文（简体） ‪(zh-hans)‬" data-dir="ltr" /><track src="https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;title=File%3AXi%27s_voice_2021.ogg&amp;lang=zh-hant&amp;trackformat=vtt&amp;origin=%2A" kind="subtitles" type="text/vtt" srclang="zh-Hant" label="中文（繁體） ‪(zh-hant)‬" data-dir="ltr" /></audio></span></span></div>
<div class="description">Recorded <a href="/wiki/100th_Anniversary_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="100th Anniversary of the Chinese Communist Party">1 July 2021</a></div></div></div></div>
</div></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" class="infobox-full-data"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1289430074" /></td></tr><tr style="display:none;"><td colspan="2" <div style="line-height: 1.6em; font-weight: bold; background-color:#FCF;text-align:center;"><div style="margin: 0 4em">Central institution membership<sup class="noprint selfreference">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Talk:Xi_Jinping" title="Talk:Xi Jinping">discuss</a></i>&#93;</sup></div></div>
<ul class="mw-collapsible-content" style="margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0; line-height: inherit;"><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 2007–: <a href="/wiki/17th_Politburo_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="17th Politburo of the Chinese Communist Party">17th</a>, <a href="/wiki/18th_Politburo_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="18th Politburo of the Chinese Communist Party">18th</a>, <a href="/wiki/19th_Politburo_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="19th Politburo of the Chinese Communist Party">19th</a>, <a href="/wiki/20th_Politburo_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="20th Politburo of the Chinese Communist Party">20th</a> Politburo Standing Committee
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 2007–: <a href="/wiki/17th_Politburo_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="17th Politburo of the Chinese Communist Party">17th</a>, <a href="/wiki/18th_Politburo_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="18th Politburo of the Chinese Communist Party">18th</a>, <a href="/wiki/19th_Politburo_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="19th Politburo of the Chinese Communist Party">19th</a>, <a href="/wiki/20th_Politburo_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="20th Politburo of the Chinese Communist Party">20th</a> Politburo
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 2007–2012: Secretary (first-ranked), 17th Central Secretariat
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 2002–: Full member, <a href="/wiki/16th_Central_Committee_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="16th Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party">16th</a>, <a href="/wiki/17th_Central_Committee_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="17th Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party">17th</a>, <a href="/wiki/18th_Central_Committee_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="18th Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party">18th</a>, <a href="/wiki/19th_Central_Committee_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="19th Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party">19th</a>, <a href="/wiki/20th_Central_Committee_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="20th Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party">20th</a> Central Committee
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 1997–2002: Alternate member, <a href="/wiki/15th_Central_Committee_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="15th Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party">15th</a> Central Committee
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 1998–: Delegate, <a href="/wiki/9th_National_People%27s_Congress" title="9th National People&#39;s Congress">9th</a>, <a href="/wiki/10th_National_People%27s_Congress" title="10th National People&#39;s Congress">10th</a>, <a href="/wiki/11th_National_People%27s_Congress" title="11th National People&#39;s Congress">11th</a>, <a href="/wiki/12th_National_People%27s_Congress" title="12th National People&#39;s Congress">12th</a>, <a href="/wiki/13th_National_People%27s_Congress" title="13th National People&#39;s Congress">13th</a>, <a href="/wiki/14th_National_People%27s_Congress" title="14th National People&#39;s Congress">14th</a> National People's Congress
</li></ul>

<div style="line-height: 1.6em; font-weight: bold; background-color:#FCF;text-align:center;"><div style="margin: 0 4em">Leading Groups and Commissions</div></div>
<ul class="mw-collapsible-content" style="margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0; line-height: inherit;"><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 2018–present: Director, <a href="/wiki/Central_Financial_and_Economic_Affairs_Commission" title="Central Financial and Economic Affairs Commission">Central Financial and Economic Affairs Commission</a>
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 2018–present: Director, <a href="/wiki/Central_Foreign_Affairs_Commission" title="Central Foreign Affairs Commission">Central Foreign Affairs Commission</a>
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 2018–2023: Director, <a href="/wiki/Central_Cyberspace_Affairs_Commission" title="Central Cyberspace Affairs Commission">Central Cyberspace Affairs Commission</a>
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 2018–present: Director, <a href="/wiki/Central_Comprehensive_Law-based_Governance_Commission" title="Central Comprehensive Law-based Governance Commission">Central Comprehensive Law-based Governance Commission</a>
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 2018–present: Director, <a href="/wiki/Central_Comprehensively_Deepening_Reforms_Commission" title="Central Comprehensively Deepening Reforms Commission">Central Comprehensively Deepening Reforms Commission</a>
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 2014–present: Leader, <a href="/wiki/Central_Leading_Group_for_Military_Reform" title="Central Leading Group for Military Reform">Leading Group for Defence and Military Reform</a>
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 2014–2018: Leader, <a href="/wiki/Central_Leading_Group_for_Internet_Security_and_Informatization" class="mw-redirect" title="Central Leading Group for Internet Security and Informatization">Leading Group for Internet Security and Informatization</a>
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 2013–present: Chairman, <a href="/wiki/National_Security_Commission_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="National Security Commission of the Chinese Communist Party">National Security Commission</a>
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 2013–2018: Leader, <a href="/wiki/Leading_Group_for_Financial_and_Economic_Affairs" class="mw-redirect" title="Leading Group for Financial and Economic Affairs">Leading Group for Financial and Economic Affairs</a>
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 2013–2018: Leader, <a href="/wiki/Central_Leading_Group_for_Comprehensively_Deepening_Reforms" class="mw-redirect" title="Central Leading Group for Comprehensively Deepening Reforms">Central Leading Group for Comprehensively Deepening Reforms</a>
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 2012–present: Leader, <a href="/wiki/Central_Leading_Group_for_Taiwan_Affairs" title="Central Leading Group for Taiwan Affairs">Central Leading Group for Taiwan Affairs</a>
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 2012–2018: Leader, <a href="/wiki/Central_Foreign_Affairs_Commission" title="Central Foreign Affairs Commission">Foreign Affairs Leading Group</a>
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 2007–2012: Leader Group for Party Building
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> c. 2007–2012: Leader, Leading Group for Activities of Deepening the Study and Practice of the Outlook of Scientific Development
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 2007–2012: Leader, <a href="/wiki/Central_Coordination_Group_for_Hong_Kong_and_Macau_Affairs" class="mw-redirect" title="Central Coordination Group for Hong Kong and Macau Affairs">Central Coordination Group for Hong Kong and Macau Affairs</a>
</li></ul>
</div>

<div class="collapsible-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" style="text-align: left;">
<div style="line-height: 1.6em; font-weight: bold; background-color:#FCF; text-align:center;"><div style="margin: 0 4em">Other offices held</div></div>
<ul class="mw-collapsible-content" style="margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0; line-height: inherit;"><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 2016–present: <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Military_Command_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" class="mw-redirect" title="Supreme Military Command of the People&#39;s Republic of China">Supreme Commander</a>, Joint Battle Command of the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army" title="People&#39;s Liberation Army">People's Liberation Army</a>
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 2010–2013: Vice Chairman, State Central Military Commission
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 2010–2012: <a href="/wiki/Vice_Chairman_of_the_Central_Military_Commission" title="Vice Chairman of the Central Military Commission">Vice Chairman, Party Central Military Commission</a>
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 2008–2013: <a href="/wiki/Vice_President_of_China" title="Vice President of China">Vice President of China</a>
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 2007–2012: President, <a href="/wiki/Central_Party_School_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" class="mw-redirect" title="Central Party School of the Chinese Communist Party">Central Party School</a>
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 2007: <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party_Committee_Secretary" title="Chinese Communist Party Committee Secretary">Party Committee Secretary</a>, Shanghai municipality
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 2002–2007: Party Secretary, Zhejiang province, director, Standing Committee of the <a href="/wiki/Zhejiang_Provincial_People%27s_Congress" title="Zhejiang Provincial People&#39;s Congress">Zhejiang Provincial People's Congress</a>
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 2002: Deputy Party Secretary &amp; acting governor, Zhejiang province
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 1999–2002: Governor, Fujian province
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 1995–2002: <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party_Deputy_Committee_Secretary" title="Chinese Communist Party Deputy Committee Secretary">Deputy Party Secretary</a>, Fujian province
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 1990–1996: Party Secretary, <a href="/wiki/Fuzhou" title="Fuzhou">Fuzhou</a>
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 1990–1996: Chairman, Standing Committee of the Fuzhou Municipal People's Congress
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 1988–1990: Party Secretary, <a href="/wiki/Ningde" title="Ningde">Ningde</a>
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 1985–1988: Deputy Mayor, Xiamen
</li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> 1983–1985: Party Secretary, <a href="/wiki/Zhengding_County" title="Zhengding County">Zhengding County</a>
</li></ul>
</div>

data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1239400231">.mw-parser-output .navbar{display:inline;font-size:88%;font-weight:normal}.mw-parser-output .navbar-collapse{float:left;text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .navbar-boxtext{word-spacing:0}.mw-parser-output .navbar ul{display:inline-block;white-space:nowrap;line-height:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::before{margin-right:-0.125em;content:"[ "}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::after{margin-left:-0.125em;content:" ]"}.mw-parser-output .navbar abbr{color:var(--color-base)!important}@media(prefers-color-scheme:dark){html.skin-theme-clientpref-os .mw-parser-output .navbar li a abbr{color:var(--color-base)!important}}@media print{.mw-parser-output .navbar{display:none!important}}</style><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Xi_Jinping_sidebar" title="Template:Xi Jinping sidebar"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Xi_Jinping_sidebar" title="Template talk:Xi Jinping sidebar"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a href="/wiki/Special:EditPage/Template:Xi_Jinping_sidebar" title="Special:EditPage/Template:Xi Jinping sidebar"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Xi Jinping</b><sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>a<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> (born 15 June 1953) is a Chinese politician who has been the <a href="/wiki/General_secretary_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" class="mw-redirect" title="General secretary of the Chinese Communist Party">general secretary of the Chinese Communist Party</a> (CCP) and <a href="/wiki/Chairman_of_the_Central_Military_Commission_(China)" title="Chairman of the Central Military Commission (China)">chairman of the Central Military Commission</a> (CMC), and thus the <a href="/wiki/Paramount_leader" title="Paramount leader">paramount leader</a> of China, since 2012. Since 2013, Xi has also served as the seventh <a href="/wiki/President_of_China" title="President of China">president of China</a>. As a member of the fifth <a href="/wiki/Generations_of_Chinese_leadership" title="Generations of Chinese leadership">generation of Chinese leadership</a>, Xi is the first CCP general secretary born after the <a href="/wiki/Proclamation_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Proclamation of the People&#39;s Republic of China">establishment of the People's Republic of China</a> (PRC).
</p><p>The son of Chinese communist veteran <a href="/wiki/Xi_Zhongxun" title="Xi Zhongxun">Xi Zhongxun</a>, Xi was exiled to rural <a href="/wiki/Yanchuan_County" title="Yanchuan County">Yanchuan County</a>, Shaanxi Province, as a teenager following his father's purge during the <a href="/wiki/Cultural_Revolution" title="Cultural Revolution">Cultural Revolution</a>. He lived in a <a href="/wiki/Yaodong" title="Yaodong">yaodong</a> in the village of Liangjiahe, where he joined the CCP after several failed attempts and worked as the local <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party_Committee_Secretary" title="Chinese Communist Party Committee Secretary">party secretary</a>. After studying <a href="/wiki/Chemical_engineering" title="Chemical engineering">chemical engineering</a> at <a href="/wiki/Tsinghua_University" title="Tsinghua University">Tsinghua University</a> as a <a href="/wiki/Worker-Peasant-Soldier_student" title="Worker-Peasant-Soldier student">worker-peasant-soldier student</a>, Xi rose through the ranks politically in China's coastal provinces. Xi was <a href="/wiki/Governor_of_Fujian" title="Governor of Fujian">governor of Fujian</a> from 1999 to 2002, before becoming governor and party secretary of neighboring <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Zhejiang" title="Politics of Zhejiang">Zhejiang</a> from 2002 to 2007. Following the dismissal of the party secretary of Shanghai, <a href="/wiki/Chen_Liangyu" title="Chen Liangyu">Chen Liangyu</a>, Xi was transferred to replace him for a brief period in 2007. He subsequently joined the <a href="/wiki/Politburo_Standing_Committee_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Politburo Standing Committee of the Chinese Communist Party">Politburo Standing Committee</a> (PSC) of the CCP the same year and was the first-ranking secretary of the <a href="/wiki/Secretariat_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Secretariat of the Chinese Communist Party">Central Secretariat</a> in October 2007. In 2008, he was designated as <a href="/wiki/Hu_Jintao" title="Hu Jintao">Hu Jintao</a>'s presumed <a href="/wiki/Succession_of_power_in_China" title="Succession of power in China">successor</a> as paramount leader. Towards this end, Xi was appointed the eighth <a href="/wiki/Vice_President_of_China" title="Vice President of China">vice president</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vice_Chairman_of_the_Central_Military_Commission" title="Vice Chairman of the Central Military Commission">vice chairman of the CMC</a>. He officially received the title of <a href="/wiki/Leadership_core" title="Leadership core">leadership core</a> from the CCP in 2016.
</p><p>While overseeing China's domestic policy, Xi has introduced far-ranging measures to enforce party discipline and strengthen internal unity. His <a href="/wiki/Anti-corruption_campaign_under_Xi_Jinping" title="Anti-corruption campaign under Xi Jinping">anti-corruption campaign</a> led to the downfall of prominent incumbent and retired CCP officials, including former PSC member <a href="/wiki/Zhou_Yongkang" title="Zhou Yongkang">Zhou Yongkang</a>. For the sake of promoting "<a href="/wiki/Common_prosperity" title="Common prosperity">common prosperity</a>", Xi has enacted a series of policies designed to increase equality, overseen <a href="/wiki/Targeted_Poverty_Alleviation" title="Targeted Poverty Alleviation">targeted poverty alleviation</a> programs as part of the <a href="/wiki/Battle_against_poverty" title="Battle against poverty">battle against poverty</a> campaign, and directed a broad crackdown in 2021 against the tech and tutoring sectors. Furthermore, he has expanded support for <a href="/wiki/State-owned_enterprises_of_China" title="State-owned enterprises of China">state-owned enterprises</a> (SOEs), emphasized advanced manufacturing and tech development, advanced <a href="/wiki/Military-civil_fusion" title="Military-civil fusion">military-civil fusion</a>, and attempted to reform China's property sector. Following the onset of the <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_mainland_China" title="COVID-19 pandemic in mainland China">COVID-19 pandemic in mainland China</a>, he initially presided over a <a href="/wiki/Zero-COVID" title="Zero-COVID">zero-COVID</a> policy from January 2020 to December 2022 before ultimately shifting towards a <a href="/wiki/Mitigation_strategy" class="mw-redirect" title="Mitigation strategy">mitigation strategy</a>.
</p><p>Xi has pursued a more aggressive foreign policy, particularly with regard to <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="China–United States relations">China's relations with the United States</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Nine-dash_line" title="Nine-dash line">nine-dash line</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Territorial_disputes_in_the_South_China_Sea" title="Territorial disputes in the South China Sea">South China Sea</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Sino-Indian_border_dispute" title="Sino-Indian border dispute">Sino-Indian border dispute</a>. Additionally, for the sake of advancing Chinese economic interests abroad, Xi has sought to expand China's influence in Africa and Eurasia by championing the <a href="/wiki/Belt_and_Road_Initiative" title="Belt and Road Initiative">Belt and Road Initiative</a>. Xi presided over a deterioration in relations between Beijing and Taipei under Taiwanese president <a href="/wiki/Tsai_Ing-wen" title="Tsai Ing-wen">Tsai Ing-wen</a>, successor of <a href="/wiki/Ma_Ying-jeou" title="Ma Ying-jeou">Ma Ying-jeou</a> whom Xi met in 2015. In 2020, Xi oversaw the passage of a <a href="/wiki/2020_Hong_Kong_national_security_law" title="2020 Hong Kong national security law">national security law in Hong Kong</a>, which clamped down on political opposition in the city, especially <a href="/wiki/Pro-democracy_camp_(Hong_Kong)" title="Pro-democracy camp (Hong Kong)">pro-democracy activists</a>.
</p><p>Since coming to power, Xi's tenure has witnessed a significant increase in <a href="/wiki/Censorship_in_China" title="Censorship in China">censorship</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mass_surveillance_in_China" title="Mass surveillance in China">mass surveillance</a>, a deterioration in <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_China" title="Human rights in China">human rights</a>, including the <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Uyghurs_in_China" title="Persecution of Uyghurs in China">persecution of Uyghurs in Xinjiang</a>, the rise of a <a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping%27s_cult_of_personality" title="Xi Jinping&#39;s cult of personality">cult of personality</a> around his leadership, and the <a href="/wiki/2018_amendment_to_the_Constitution_of_China" title="2018 amendment to the Constitution of China">removal</a> of term limits for the presidency in 2018. Xi's political ideas and principles, known as <a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping_Thought" title="Xi Jinping Thought">Xi Jinping Thought</a>, have been incorporated into the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Constitution of the Chinese Communist Party">party</a> and <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_China" title="Constitution of China">national constitutions</a>. As the central figure of the fifth generation of leadership of the PRC, Xi has centralized institutional power by taking on multiple positions, including new CCP committees on national security, economic and social reforms, military restructuring and modernization, and the internet. In October 2022, Xi secured a third term as CCP General Secretary, and was re-elected state president for a third term in March 2023.
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886046785">.mw-parser-output .toclimit-2 .toclevel-1 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-3 .toclevel-2 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-4 .toclevel-3 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-5 .toclevel-4 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-6 .toclevel-5 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-7 .toclevel-6 ul{display:none}</style><div class="toclimit-3"><meta property="mw:PageProp/toc" /></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Early_life_and_education">Early life and education</h2></div>
<p>Xi Jinping was born on 15 June 1953 in <a href="/wiki/Beijing" title="Beijing">Beijing</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWong202321_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWong202321-3"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>2<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> the third child of <a href="/wiki/Xi_Zhongxun" title="Xi Zhongxun">Xi Zhongxun</a> and his second wife <a href="/wiki/Qi_Xin" title="Qi Xin">Qi Xin</a>. After the <a href="/wiki/Proclamation_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Proclamation of the People&#39;s Republic of China">founding of the PRC</a> in 1949, Xi's father held a series of posts, including the chief of the <a href="/wiki/Publicity_Department_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Publicity Department of the Chinese Communist Party">Publicity Department of the Chinese Communist Party</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vice_Premier_of_China" title="Vice Premier of China">vice-premier</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vice_Chairperson_of_the_Standing_Committee_of_the_National_People%27s_Congress" title="Vice Chairperson of the Standing Committee of the National People&#39;s Congress">vice chairperson of the National People's Congress</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>3<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi had two older sisters, <a href="/wiki/Qi_Qiaoqiao" title="Qi Qiaoqiao">Qi Qiaoqiao</a> (齐桥桥), born in 1949 and Qi An'an (齐安安), born in 1952.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>4<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi's father was from <a href="/wiki/Fuping_County,_Shaanxi" title="Fuping County, Shaanxi">Fuping County</a>, Shaanxi.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>5<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Xi went to <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Bayi_School" title="Beijing Bayi School">Beijing Bayi School</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>6<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-newyorker2_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-newyorker2-8"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>7<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and then Beijing No. 25 School,<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>8<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> in the 1960s. He became friends with <a href="/wiki/Liu_He_(politician)" title="Liu He (politician)">Liu He</a>, who attended <a href="/wiki/Beijing_101_Middle_School" title="Beijing 101 Middle School">Beijing No. 101 School</a> in the same district, and who later became China's vice premier and a close advisor to Xi after he became China's paramount leader.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>9<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>10<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 1963, when Xi was ten years old, his father was purged from the CCP and sent to work in a factory in <a href="/wiki/Luoyang" title="Luoyang">Luoyang</a>, Henan.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBouée201093_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBouée201093-12"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>11<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In May 1966, the <a href="/wiki/Cultural_Revolution" title="Cultural Revolution">Cultural Revolution</a> cut short Xi's secondary education when all secondary classes were halted for students to criticise and fight their teachers. Student militants ransacked the Xi family home and one of Xi's sisters, Xi Heping, "was persecuted to death".<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>12<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Buckley-2015_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Buckley-2015-14"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>13<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Later, his mother was forced to publicly denounce his father, as he was paraded before a crowd as an enemy of the revolution. His father was later imprisoned in 1968 when Xi was aged 15. In 1968, Xi submitted an application to the Bayi School's Reform Committee and insisted on leaving Beijing for the countryside.<sup id="cite_ref-g605_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-g605-15"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>14<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> On January 13, 1969, they left Beijing and arrived in Liangjiahe Village, <a href="/wiki/Yan%27an" title="Yan&#39;an">Yan'an</a>, Shaanxi, alongside the Mao Zedong's <a href="/wiki/Down_to_the_Countryside_Movement" title="Down to the Countryside Movement">Down to the Countryside Movement</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>15<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The rural areas of Yan'an were very backward,<sup id="cite_ref-Page-2020_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Page-2020-17"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>16<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> which created a big gap for Xi as a teenager. He once recalled that he had to overcome "five hurdles" (<a href="/wiki/Flea" title="Flea">flea</a>, food, life, labor and thought hurdle),<sup id="cite_ref-j429_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-j429-18"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>17<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and the experience led him to feel affinity with the rural poor.<sup id="cite_ref-Page-2020_17-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Page-2020-17"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>16<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> After a few months, unable to stand rural life, he ran away to Beijing. He was arrested during a crackdown on deserters from the countryside and sent to a work camp to dig ditches. He later returned to the village, under the persuasion of his aunt Qi Yun and uncle Wei Zhenwu.<sup id="cite_ref-x837_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-x837-19"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>18<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He worked as the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party_Committee_Secretary" title="Chinese Communist Party Committee Secretary">party secretary</a> of Liangjiahe, where he lived in a <a href="/wiki/Yaodong" title="Yaodong">cave house</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>19<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>He then spent a total of seven years in <a href="/wiki/Yanchuan_County" title="Yanchuan County">Yanchuan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>20<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>21<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 1973, Yanchuan County assigned Xi Jinping to Zhaojiahe Village in Jiajianping Commune to lead social education efforts.<sup id="cite_ref-b772_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-b772-23"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>22<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Due to his effective work and strong rapport with the villagers, the community expressed a desire to keep him there. However, after Liangjiahe Village advocated for his return, Xi went back in July that same year. Liang Yuming (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh">梁玉明</span></span>) and Liang Youhua (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh">梁有华</span></span>), the village branch secretaries, supported his application to the Chinese Communist Party.<sup id="cite_ref-k447_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-k447-24"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>23<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Yet, due to his father, Xi Zhongxun, still facing political persecution, the application was initially blocked by higher authorities.<sup id="cite_ref-newyorker2_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-newyorker2-8"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>7<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Despite submitting ten applications, it wasn't until the new commune secretary, Bai Guangxing (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh">白光兴</span></span>), recognized Xi's capabilities that his application was forwarded to the CCP Yanchuan County Committee and approved in early 1974.<sup id="cite_ref-v256_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-v256-25"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>24<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Around that time, as Liangjiahe village underwent leadership changes, Xi was recommended to become the Party branch chairman of the Liangjiahe Brigade.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>25<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>26<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>After taking office, Xi noted that <a href="/wiki/Mianyang" title="Mianyang">Mianyang</a>, Sichuan was using <a href="/wiki/Biogas" title="Biogas">biogas</a> technology and, given the fuel shortages in his village, he traveled to Mianyang to learn about biogas digesters.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>27<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Upon returning, he successfully implemented the technology in Liangjiahe, marking a breakthrough in Shaanxi that soon spread throughout the region.<sup id="cite_ref-q526_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-q526-29"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>28<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Additionally, he led efforts to drill wells for water supply, establish iron industry cooperatives, reclaim land, plant flue-cured tobacco, and set up sales outlets to address the village's production and economic challenges.<sup id="cite_ref-m580_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-m580-30"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>29<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-f125_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-f125-31"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>30<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 1975, when Yanchuan County was allocated a spot at <a href="/wiki/Tsinghua_University" title="Tsinghua University">Tsinghua University</a>, the CCP Yanchuan County Committee recommended Xi for admission.<sup id="cite_ref-w795_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-w795-32"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>31<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> From 1975 to 1979, Xi studied <a href="/wiki/Chemical_engineering" title="Chemical engineering">chemical engineering</a> at Tsinghua University as a <a href="/wiki/Worker-Peasant-Soldier_student" title="Worker-Peasant-Soldier student">worker-peasant-soldier student</a> in Beijing.<sup id="cite_ref-k525_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-k525-33"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>32<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESimonCong200928–29_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESimonCong200928–29-34"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>33<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Early_political_career">Early political career</h2></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Central_Military_Commission">Central Military Commission</h3></div>
<p>After graduating in April 1979, Xi was assigned to the General Office of the State Council and the General Office of the CPC Central Military Commission, where he served as one of three secretaries to <a href="/wiki/Geng_Biao" title="Geng Biao">Geng Biao</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-j608_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-j608-35"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>34<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> a member of the CPC Central Committee's Political Bureau and Minister of Defense.<sup id="cite_ref-i815_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-i815-36"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>35<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-newyorker2_8-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-newyorker2-8"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>7<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Hebei">Hebei</h3></div>
<p>On March 25, 1982, Xi was appointed deputy party secretary of <a href="/wiki/Zhengding_County" title="Zhengding County">Zhengding County</a> in Hebei.<sup id="cite_ref-r135_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-r135-37"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>36<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>37<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Together with Lü Yulan (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh">吕玉兰</span></span>), the other deputy party secretary of Zhengding, Xi wrote a letter to the central government addressing the excessive requisitions that burdened local farmers.<sup id="cite_ref-k440_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-k440-39"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>38<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Their efforts successfully convinced the center government to reduce the annual requisition amount by 14 million kilograms.<sup id="cite_ref-b772_23-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-b772-23"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>22<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 1983, Zhengding adjusted its agricultural structure, leading to a significant increase in farmers' incomes from 148 yuan to over 400 yuan in 1984,<sup id="cite_ref-g703_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-g703-40"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>39<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> thoroughly solving the county's economic issues.<sup id="cite_ref-p256_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-p256-41"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>40<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>As the secretary of the CCP Zhengding County Committee in July 1983,<sup id="cite_ref-d688_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-d688-42"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>41<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-k440_39-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-k440-39"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>38<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi initiated several development projects, including the development of "Nine Articles of Zhengding talents",<sup id="cite_ref-d688_42-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-d688-42"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>41<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> the construction of Changshan Park,<sup id="cite_ref-p482_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-p482-43"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>42<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> the restoration of the <a href="/wiki/Longxing_Temple" title="Longxing Temple">Longxing Temple</a>, the formation of a tourism company, and the establishment of the Rongguo Mansion and Zhengding Table Tennis Base.<sup id="cite_ref-h057_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-h057-44"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>43<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He also persuaded the China Teleplay Production Center to set the filming base of <a href="/wiki/Dream_of_the_Red_Chamber_(1987_TV_series)" title="Dream of the Red Chamber (1987 TV series)">Dream of the Red Mansions</a> in Zhengding and secured 3.5 million yuan to build Rongguo Mansion,<sup id="cite_ref-s517_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-s517-45"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>44<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> which significantly boosted the county's tourism industry, generating 17.61 million yuan in revenue that year.<sup id="cite_ref-d992_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-d992-46"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>45<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Additionally, Xi invited prominent figures such as <a href="/wiki/Hua_Luogeng" title="Hua Luogeng">Hua Luogeng</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yu_Guangyuan" title="Yu Guangyuan">Yu Guangyuan</a>, Pan Chengxiao to visit Zhengding,<sup id="cite_ref-v796_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-v796-47"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>46<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> which eventually led to the development of the county's "semi-urban" strategy,<sup id="cite_ref-h057_44-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-h057-44"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>43<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> leveraging its proximity to Shijiazhuang for diverse business growth.<sup id="cite_ref-f453_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-f453-48"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>47<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-q342_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-q342-49"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>48<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In September 1984, during a briefing session chaired by He Zai, the secretary-general of the <a href="/wiki/Central_Organization_Department" class="mw-redirect" title="Central Organization Department">Central Organization Department</a>, Xi Jinping's strategic vision and comprehensive understanding of Zhengding County's development were highlighted.<sup id="cite_ref-d652_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-d652-50"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>49<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He Zai, along with <a href="/wiki/Wei_Jianxing" title="Wei Jianxing">Wei Jianxing</a>, deputy head of the CCP Central Organization Department, communicated these findings to <a href="/wiki/Hu_Yaobang" title="Hu Yaobang">Hu Yaobang</a>, describing Xi as a leader with a strategic outlook and a strong alliance ideology between workers and peasants.<sup id="cite_ref-k053_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-k053-51"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>50<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-p946_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-p946-52"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>51<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 1985, Xi participated in a study tour on corn processing and traveled to <a href="/wiki/Iowa" title="Iowa">Iowa</a>, US,<sup id="cite_ref-z177_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-z177-53"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>52<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> to study agricultural production and corn processing technology.<sup id="cite_ref-o756_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-o756-54"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>53<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-d652_50-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-d652-50"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>49<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> During his visit to the U.S., the CCP Central Organization Department decided to transfer him to <a href="/wiki/Xiamen" title="Xiamen">Xiamen</a> as a member of the Standing Committee of the CCP Xiamen Municipal Committee and as vice mayor.<sup id="cite_ref-k053_51-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-k053-51"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>50<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Fujian">Fujian</h3></div>
<p>Arriving in Xiamen as vice-mayor in June 1985, Xi drafted the first strategic plan for the development of the city, the Xiamen Economic and Social Development Strategy for 1985–2000.<sup id="cite_ref-u803_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-u803-55"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>54<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> From August, Along with helping to prepare <a href="/wiki/Xiamen_Airlines" class="mw-redirect" title="Xiamen Airlines">Xiamen Airlines</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-m820_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-m820-56"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>55<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> the Xiamen Economic Information Center,<sup id="cite_ref-g215_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-g215-57"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>56<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and the Xiamen Special Administrative Region Road Project, etc., he oversaw the resolution for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yundang_Lake&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yundang Lake (page does not exist)">Yundang Lake</a>'s comprehensive treatments.<sup id="cite_ref-b381_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-b381-58"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>57<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He married <a href="/wiki/Peng_Liyuan" title="Peng Liyuan">Peng Liyuan</a> then in Xiamen.<sup id="cite_ref-z629_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-z629-59"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>58<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-p383_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-p383-60"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>59<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>He started serving as the head of a region after being appointed just as the secretary of <a href="/wiki/Ningde" title="Ningde">Ningde</a> in September 1988.<sup id="cite_ref-c338_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-c338-61"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>60<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Ningde's economy was far worse at that time than that of Fuzhou and Xiamen.<sup id="cite_ref-g505_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-g505-62"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>61<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi organized his work log and experience during his Ningde period into his book <i>Getting out of Poverty</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-b584_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-b584-63"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>62<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and handled the local poverty eradicating efforts and local CCP building projects.<sup id="cite_ref-b250_64-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-b250-64"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>63<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The CCP Fujian Provincial Committee decided in May 1990 to assign Xi to <a href="/wiki/Fuzhou_City" class="mw-redirect" title="Fuzhou City">Fuzhou City</a> as the Municipal Committee Secretary.<sup id="cite_ref-o840_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-o840-65"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>64<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In 1997, he was named an alternate member of the <a href="/wiki/15th_Central_Committee_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="15th Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party">15th CCP Central Committee</a>. In 1999, he was promoted to the office of Vice Governor of Fujian, and became governor a year later. Xi proposed the concept of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Golden_Triangle_at_Min_River&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Golden Triangle at Min River (page does not exist)">Golden Triangle at Min River</a> (<a href="/wiki/Chinese_language" title="Chinese language">Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh">闽江口金三角经济圈</span>) and oversaw the construction of the Fuzhou 3820 Project Master Plan,<sup id="cite_ref-l369_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-l369-66"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>65<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> which outlines Fuzhou City's growth strategy for 3, 8, and 20 years.<sup id="cite_ref-f182_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-f182-67"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>66<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He concentrated on the development of <a href="/wiki/Changle_International_Airport" class="mw-redirect" title="Changle International Airport">Changle International Airport</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Min_River_Water_Transfer_Project&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Min River Water Transfer Project (page does not exist)">Min River Water Transfer Project</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fuzhou_Telecommunication_Hub&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fuzhou Telecommunication Hub (page does not exist)">Fuzhou Telecommunication Hub</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Fuzhou_Port" class="mw-redirect" title="Fuzhou Port">Fuzhou Port</a>, among others. He concentrated on attracting Taiwanese and foreign investment,<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>67<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> establishing <a href="/w/index.php?title=Southwest_TPV_Electronics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Southwest TPV Electronics (page does not exist)">Southwest TPV Electronics</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Southeast_Automobile&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Southeast Automobile (page does not exist)">Southeast Automobile</a> in Fuzhou, and fostering <a href="/wiki/Fuyao_Glass" class="mw-redirect" title="Fuyao Glass">Fuyao Glass</a>, <a href="/wiki/Newland_Digital_Technology" title="Newland Digital Technology">Newland Digital Technology</a> and other manufacturing firms.<sup id="cite_ref-o840_65-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-o840-65"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>64<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Furthermore, he rehabilitated local cultural landmarks, including as the <a href="/wiki/Sanfang_Qixiang" title="Sanfang Qixiang">Sanfang Qixiang</a> in Fuzhou, advanced urban renewal initiatives, and effectively addressed the issue of poverty alleviation on <a href="/wiki/Pingtan_Island" title="Pingtan Island">Pingtan Island</a>. In 1995, Xi Jinping was elevated to deputy secretary of the <a href="/wiki/Fujian_Provincial_Committee_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Fujian Provincial Committee of the Chinese Communist Party">Fujian Provincial Committee of the Chinese Communist Party</a> and served as <a href="/wiki/Governor_of_Fujian" title="Governor of Fujian">Governor of Fujian</a> from 1999 to 2002, during which he presented the notion of "<a href="/wiki/Megalopolises_in_China" title="Megalopolises in China">Megalopolises</a>" and advocated for the inter-island growth strategy of Fuzhou and Xiamen, which motivated local officials to swiftly overcome the repercussions of the <a href="/wiki/Lai_Changxing" title="Lai Changxing">Yuanhua smuggling case</a> (<a href="/wiki/Chinese_language" title="Chinese language">Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh">远华走私案</span>) and adopt a new development strategy.<sup id="cite_ref-x752_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-x752-69"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>68<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi also oversaw the development of "Digital Fujian", including the province's complaint hotline into the "<a href="/wiki/12345_hotline" title="12345 hotline">12345 Citizen Service Platform</a>," so enhancing organizational efficiency.<sup id="cite_ref-l369_66-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-l369-66"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>65<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Zhejiang">Zhejiang</h3></div>
<p>In 2002, Xi left Fujian and took up leading political positions in neighbouring Zhejiang. He eventually took over as <a href="/wiki/Fujian_Provincial_Committee_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Fujian Provincial Committee of the Chinese Communist Party">provincial Party Committee</a> secretary after several months as acting governor, occupying a top provincial office for the first time in his career. In 2002, he was elected a full member of the <a href="/wiki/16th_Central_Committee_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="16th Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party">16th Central Committee</a>, marking his ascension to the national stage. While in Zhejiang, Xi presided over reported growth rates averaging 14% per year.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>69<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> During this period, Zhejiang increasingly transitioned away from heavy industry.<sup id="cite_ref-:Chatwin_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:Chatwin-71"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>70<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 121">&#58;&#8202;121&#8202;</span></sup> His career in Zhejiang was marked by a tough and straightforward stance against corrupt officials. This earned him a name in the national media and drew the attention of China's top leaders.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>71<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Between 2004 and 2007, <a href="/wiki/Li_Qiang" title="Li Qiang">Li Qiang</a> acted as Xi's chief of staff through his position as secretary-general of the <a href="/wiki/Zhejiang_Provincial_Committee_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Zhejiang Provincial Committee of the Chinese Communist Party">Zhejiang Party Committee</a>, where they developed close mutual ties.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>72<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Shanghai">Shanghai</h3></div>
<p>Following the dismissal of <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_Secretary_of_Shanghai" class="mw-redirect" title="Communist Party Secretary of Shanghai">Shanghai Party secretary</a> <a href="/wiki/Chen_Liangyu" title="Chen Liangyu">Chen Liangyu</a> in September 2006 due to a <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_pension_scandal" title="Shanghai pension scandal">social security fund scandal</a>, Xi was transferred to Shanghai in March 2007, where he was the party secretary there for seven months.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>73<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>74<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In Shanghai, Xi avoided controversy and was known for strictly observing party discipline. For example, Shanghai administrators attempted to earn favour with him by arranging a special train to shuttle him between Shanghai and <a href="/wiki/Hangzhou" title="Hangzhou">Hangzhou</a> for him to complete handing off his work to his successor as Zhejiang party secretary <a href="/wiki/Zhao_Hongzhu" title="Zhao Hongzhu">Zhao Hongzhu</a>. However, Xi reportedly refused to take the train, citing a loosely enforced party regulation that stipulated that special trains can only be reserved for "national leaders".<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>75<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> While in Shanghai, he worked on preserving unity of the local party organisation. He pledged there would be no 'purges' during his administration, despite the fact many local officials were thought to have been implicated in the Chen Liangyu corruption scandal.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELam201556_77-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELam201556-77"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>76<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> On most issues, Xi largely echoed the line of the central leadership.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>77<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Politburo_Standing_Committee">Politburo Standing Committee</h2></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:President_George_W._Bush_with_Vice_President_Xi_Jinping.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/President_George_W._Bush_with_Vice_President_Xi_Jinping.jpg/250px-President_George_W._Bush_with_Vice_President_Xi_Jinping.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="180" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/President_George_W._Bush_with_Vice_President_Xi_Jinping.jpg/500px-President_George_W._Bush_with_Vice_President_Xi_Jinping.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="514" data-file-height="371" /></a><figcaption>Xi Jinping greeting U.S. president <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush" title="George W. Bush">George W. Bush</a> in August 2008</figcaption></figure>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Dmitry_Medvedev_in_China_28_September_2010-6.jpeg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Dmitry_Medvedev_in_China_28_September_2010-6.jpeg/250px-Dmitry_Medvedev_in_China_28_September_2010-6.jpeg" decoding="async" width="250" height="207" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Dmitry_Medvedev_in_China_28_September_2010-6.jpeg/500px-Dmitry_Medvedev_in_China_28_September_2010-6.jpeg 1.5x" data-file-width="887" data-file-height="735" /></a><figcaption>Xi Jinping with Russian president <a href="/wiki/Dmitry_Medvedev" title="Dmitry Medvedev">Dmitry Medvedev</a> on 28 September 2010</figcaption></figure>
<p>Xi was appointed to the nine-man PSC at the <a href="/wiki/17th_National_Congress_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="17th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party">17th Party Congress</a> in October 2007. He was ranked above <a href="/wiki/Li_Keqiang" title="Li Keqiang">Li Keqiang</a>, an indication that he was going to succeed Hu Jintao as China's <a href="/wiki/Succession_of_power_in_China" title="Succession of power in China">next leader</a>. In addition, Xi served in the CCP's <a href="/wiki/Secretariat_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Secretariat of the Chinese Communist Party">Central Secretariat</a>. This assessment was further supported at the <a href="/wiki/11th_National_People%27s_Congress" title="11th National People&#39;s Congress">11th National People's Congress</a> in March 2008, when Xi was elected as vice president of the PRC.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>78<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Following his elevation, Xi held a broad range of portfolios. He was put in charge of the comprehensive preparations for the <a href="/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics" title="2008 Summer Olympics">2008 Summer Olympics</a> in Beijing, as well as being the central government's leading figure in Hong Kong and Macau affairs. In addition, he also became the new president of the <a href="/wiki/Central_Party_School_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" class="mw-redirect" title="Central Party School of the Chinese Communist Party">Central Party School</a> of the CCP, its cadre-training and ideological education wing. In the wake of the <a href="/wiki/2008_Sichuan_earthquake" title="2008 Sichuan earthquake">2008 Sichuan earthquake</a>, Xi visited disaster areas in <a href="/wiki/Shaanxi" title="Shaanxi">Shaanxi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gansu" title="Gansu">Gansu</a>. He made his first foreign trip as vice president to North Korea, Mongolia, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Yemen from 17 to 25 June 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>79<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> After the Olympics, Xi was assigned the post of committee chair for the preparations of the <a href="/wiki/60th_anniversary_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="60th anniversary of the People&#39;s Republic of China">60th Anniversary Celebrations</a> of the founding of the PRC. He was also reportedly at the helm of a top-level CCP committee dubbed the <a href="/wiki/6521_Project" title="6521 Project">6521 Project</a>, which was charged with ensuring social stability during a series of politically sensitive anniversaries in 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>80<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Xi's position as the apparent successor to become the paramount leader was threatened with the rapid rise of <a href="/wiki/Bo_Xilai" title="Bo Xilai">Bo Xilai</a>, the party secretary of <a href="/wiki/Chongqing" title="Chongqing">Chongqing</a> at the time. Bo was expected to join the PSC at the <a href="/wiki/18th_National_Congress_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="18th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party">18th Party Congress</a>, with most expecting that he would try to eventually maneuver himself into replacing Xi.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>81<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Bo's policies in Chongqing inspired imitations throughout China and received praise from Xi himself during Xi's visit to Chongqing in 2010. Records of praises from Xi were later erased after he became paramount leader. Bo's downfall would come with the <a href="/wiki/Wang_Lijun_incident" title="Wang Lijun incident">Wang Lijun incident</a>, which opened the door for Xi to come to power without challengers.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>82<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Xi is considered one of the most successful members of the <a href="/wiki/Princelings" title="Princelings">Princelings</a>, a quasi-clique of politicians who are descendants of early Chinese Communist revolutionaries. Former prime minister of Singapore, <a href="/wiki/Lee_Kuan_Yew" title="Lee Kuan Yew">Lee Kuan Yew</a>, when asked about Xi, said he felt he was "a thoughtful man who has gone through many trials and tribulations."<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>83<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Lee also commented: "I would put him in the <a href="/wiki/Nelson_Mandela" title="Nelson Mandela">Nelson Mandela</a> class of persons. A person with enormous emotional stability who does not allow his personal misfortunes or sufferings affect his judgment. In other words, he is impressive."<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>84<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Former U.S. Treasury Secretary <a href="/wiki/Henry_Paulson" title="Henry Paulson">Henry Paulson</a> described Xi as "the kind of guy who knows how to get things over the goal line."<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>85<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Australian prime minister <a href="/wiki/Kevin_Rudd" title="Kevin Rudd">Kevin Rudd</a> said that Xi "has sufficient reformist, party and military background to be very much his own man."<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>86<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Trips_as_Vice_President">Trips as Vice President</h3></div>
<p>In February 2009, in his capacity as vice president, Xi embarked on a tour of Latin America, visiting Mexico, Jamaica,<sup id="cite_ref-JIS-2009_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JIS-2009-88"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>87<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Colombia, Venezuela,<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>88<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Brazil,<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>89<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and Malta, after which he returned to China.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>90<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> On 11 February 2009, while visiting Mexico, Xi spoke in front of a group of <a href="/wiki/Overseas_Chinese" title="Overseas Chinese">overseas Chinese</a> and explained China's contributions during the international financial crisis, saying that it was "the greatest contribution towards the whole of human race, made by China, to prevent its 1.37&#160;billion people from hunger."<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>b<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He went on to remark: "There are some bored foreigners, with full stomachs, who have nothing better to do than point fingers at us. First, China doesn't export revolution; second, China doesn't export hunger and poverty; third, China doesn't come and cause you headaches. What more is there to be said?"<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>c<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>91<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The story was reported on some local television stations. The news led to a flood of discussions on Chinese Internet forums and it was reported that the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs was caught off-guard by Xi's remarks, as the actual video was shot by some accompanying Hong Kong reporters and broadcast on Hong Kong TV, which then turned up on various Internet video websites.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>92<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Xi_Jinping_Iowa_house.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Xi_Jinping_Iowa_house.jpg/250px-Xi_Jinping_Iowa_house.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="188" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Xi_Jinping_Iowa_house.jpg/500px-Xi_Jinping_Iowa_house.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1706" data-file-height="1280" /></a><figcaption>The Muscatine, Iowa house where Xi stayed with an American family during a 1985 agricultural visit to the United States. The home was turned into a museum decades later.</figcaption></figure>
<p>In the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>, Xi visited Belgium, Germany, Bulgaria, Hungary and Romania from 7 to 21 October 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>93<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He visited Japan, South Korea, Cambodia, and Myanmar on his Asian trip from 14 to 22 December 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>94<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He later visited the United States, Ireland and Turkey in February 2012. This visit included meeting with then U.S. president <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> at the White House and vice president <a href="/wiki/Joe_Biden" title="Joe Biden">Joe Biden</a> (with Biden as the official host);<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>95<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and stops in California and <a href="/wiki/Iowa" title="Iowa">Iowa</a>. In Iowa, he met with the family that previously hosted him during his 1985 tour as a <a href="/wiki/Hebei" title="Hebei">Hebei</a> provincial official.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>96<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Accession_to_top_posts">Accession to top posts</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Generations_of_Chinese_leadership" title="Generations of Chinese leadership">Generations of Chinese leadership</a> and <a href="/wiki/Succession_of_power_in_China" title="Succession of power in China">Succession of power in China</a></div>
<p>A few months before his ascendancy to the party leadership, Xi disappeared from official media coverage and cancelled meetings with foreign officials for several weeks beginning on 1 September 2012, causing rumors.<sup id="cite_ref-newyorker2_8-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-newyorker2-8"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>7<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He then reappeared on 15 September.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>97<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> On 15 November 2012, Xi was elected to the posts of general secretary of the CCP and chairman of the CMC by the <a href="/wiki/18th_Central_Committee_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="18th Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party">18th Central Committee of the CCP</a>. This made him, informally, the <a href="/wiki/Paramount_leader" title="Paramount leader">paramount leader</a> and the first to be born after the founding of the PRC. The following day Xi led the new line-up of the PSC onto the stage in their first public appearance.<sup id="cite_ref-BBCconfirm2_101-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBCconfirm2-101"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>98<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The PSC was reduced from nine to seven, with Xi and Li Keqiang retaining their seats; the other five members were new.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>99<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>100<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>101<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In a marked departure from the common practice of Chinese leaders, Xi's first speech as general secretary was plainly worded and did not include any political slogans or mention his predecessors.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>102<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi mentioned the aspirations of the average person, remarking, "Our people ... expect better education, more stable jobs, better income, more reliable social security, medical care of a higher standard, more comfortable living conditions, and a more beautiful environment." Xi also vowed to tackle corruption at the highest levels, alluding that it would threaten the CCP's survival; he was reticent about far-reaching economic reforms.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>103<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In December 2012, Xi visited <a href="/wiki/Guangdong" title="Guangdong">Guangdong</a> in his first trip outside Beijing since taking the Party leadership. The overarching theme of the trip was to call for further economic reform and a strengthened military. Xi visited the statue of Deng Xiaoping and his trip was described as following in the footsteps of <a href="/wiki/Deng_Xiaoping#Resignation_and_1992_southern_tour" title="Deng Xiaoping">Deng's own southern trip in 1992</a>, which provided the impetus for further economic reforms in China after conservative party leaders stalled many of Deng's reforms in the aftermath of the <a href="/wiki/1989_Tiananmen_Square_protests_and_massacre" title="1989 Tiananmen Square protests and massacre">1989 Tiananmen Square protests and massacre</a>. On his trip, Xi consistently alluded to his signature slogan, the "Chinese Dream". "This dream can be said to be the dream of a strong nation. And for the military, it is a dream of a strong military," Xi told sailors.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>104<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi's trip was significant in that he departed from the established convention of Chinese leaders' travel routines in multiple ways. Rather than dining out, Xi and his entourage ate regular hotel buffet. He travelled in a large van with his colleagues rather than a fleet of limousines, and did not restrict traffic on the parts of the highway he travelled.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>105<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Xi was elected president on 14 March 2013, in a confirmation vote by the <a href="/wiki/12th_National_People%27s_Congress" title="12th National People&#39;s Congress">12th National People's Congress</a> in Beijing. He received 2,952 for, one vote against, and three abstentions.<sup id="cite_ref-BBCconfirm2_101-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBCconfirm2-101"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>98<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He replaced Hu Jintao, who retired after serving two terms.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>106<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> On 17 March, Xi and his new ministers arranged a meeting with the <a href="/wiki/Leung_Chun-ying_as_Chief_Executive_of_Hong_Kong" class="mw-redirect" title="Leung Chun-ying as Chief Executive of Hong Kong">chief executive of Hong Kong</a>, <a href="/wiki/CY_Leung" class="mw-redirect" title="CY Leung">CY Leung</a>, confirming his support for Leung.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>107<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Within hours of his election, Xi discussed <a href="/wiki/Cyber_security" class="mw-redirect" title="Cyber security">cyber security</a> and North Korea with U.S. President Barack Obama over the phone. Obama announced the visits of treasury and state secretaries <a href="/wiki/Jack_Lew" title="Jack Lew">Jack Lew</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_F._Kerry" class="mw-redirect" title="John F. Kerry">John F. Kerry</a> to China the following week.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>108<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Leadership">Leadership</h2></div>
