<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/China_under_Xi_Jinping" class="mw-redirect" title="China under Xi Jinping">China under Xi Jinping</a></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Anti-corruption_campaign">Anti-corruption campaign</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Anti-corruption_campaign_under_Xi_Jinping" title="Anti-corruption campaign under Xi Jinping">Anti-corruption campaign under Xi Jinping</a></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1224211176">.mw-parser-output .quotebox{background-color:#F9F9F9;border:1px solid #aaa;box-sizing:border-box;padding:10px;font-size:88%;max-width:100%}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatleft{margin:.5em 1.4em .8em 0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatright{margin:.5em 0 .8em 1.4em}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.centered{overflow:hidden;position:relative;margin:.5em auto .8em auto}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatleft span,.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatright span{font-style:inherit}.mw-parser-output .quotebox>blockquote{margin:0;padding:0;border-left:0;font-family:inherit;font-size:inherit}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-title{text-align:center;font-size:110%;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote>:first-child{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote:last-child>:last-child{margin-bottom:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote.quoted:before{font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;font-weight:bold;font-size:large;color:gray;content:" “ ";vertical-align:-45%;line-height:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote.quoted:after{font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;font-weight:bold;font-size:large;color:gray;content:" ” ";line-height:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .left-aligned{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .right-aligned{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .center-aligned{text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .quote-title,.mw-parser-output .quotebox .quotebox-quote{display:block}.mw-parser-output .quotebox cite{display:block;font-style:normal}@media screen and (max-width:640px){.mw-parser-output .quotebox{width:100%!important;margin:0 0 .8em!important;float:none!important}}</style><div class="quotebox pullquote floatright" style="width:25em; ;">
<blockquote class="quotebox-quote left-aligned" style="">
<p>"To speak the truth" means to focus on the nature of things, to speak frankly, and follow the truth. This is an important embodiment of a leading official's characteristics of truth seeking, embodying justice, devotion to public interests, and uprightness. Moreover, he highlighted that the premise of telling the truth is to listen to the truth.
</p>
</blockquote>
<div style="padding-bottom: 0; padding-top: 0.5em"><cite class="left-aligned" style="">— Xi Jinping during a speech in 2012<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>109<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></cite></div>
</div>
<p>Xi vowed to crack down on corruption immediately after he ascended to power. In his inaugural speech as general secretary, Xi mentioned that fighting corruption was one of the toughest challenges for the party.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>110<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> A few months into his term, Xi outlined the <a href="/wiki/Eight-point_Regulation" title="Eight-point Regulation">Eight-point Regulation</a>, listing rules intended to curb corruption and waste during official party business; it aimed at stricter discipline on the conduct of officials. Xi vowed to root out "tigers and flies," that is, high-ranking officials and ordinary party functionaries.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>111<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Xi initiated cases against former CMC vice chairmen <a href="/wiki/Xu_Caihou" title="Xu Caihou">Xu Caihou</a> and <a href="/wiki/Guo_Boxiong" title="Guo Boxiong">Guo Boxiong</a>, former PSC member and security chief <a href="/wiki/Zhou_Yongkang" title="Zhou Yongkang">Zhou Yongkang</a> and former Hu Jintao chief aide <a href="/wiki/Ling_Jihua" title="Ling Jihua">Ling Jihua</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>112<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Along with new disciplinary chief <a href="/wiki/Wang_Qishan" title="Wang Qishan">Wang Qishan</a>, Xi's <a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping%E2%80%93Li_Keqiang_Administration" title="Xi Jinping–Li Keqiang Administration">administration</a> spearheaded the formation of "centrally-dispatched inspection teams". These were cross-jurisdictional squads whose task was to gain understanding of the operations of provincial and local party organizations, and enforce party discipline mandated by Beijing. Work teams had the effect of identifying and initiating investigations of high-ranking officials. Over one hundred provincial-ministerial level officials were implicated during a nationwide anti-corruption campaign. These included former and current regional officials, leading figures of state-owned enterprises and central government organs, and generals. Within the first two years of the campaign alone, over 200,000 officials received warnings, fines, and demotions.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHeilmann201762–75_116-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHeilmann201762–75-116"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>113<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The campaign has led to the downfall of prominent incumbent and retired CCP officials, including members of the PSC.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>114<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi's anti-corruption campaign is seen by critics, such as <i><a href="/wiki/The_Economist" title="The Economist">The Economist</a></i>, as a political tool to remove potential opponents and consolidate power.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>115<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>116<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi's establishment of a new anti-corruption agency, the National Supervision Commission, ranked higher than the supreme court, has been described by <a href="/wiki/Amnesty_International" title="Amnesty International">Amnesty International</a> as a "systemic threat to human rights" that "places tens of millions of people at the mercy of a secretive and virtually unaccountable system that is above the law."<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>117<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>118<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> As of 2023, approximately 2.3 million government officials have been prosecuted.<sup id="cite_ref-Jin-2023_122-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jin-2023-122"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>119<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 129">&#58;&#8202;129&#8202;</span></sup> In January 2018, the Xi launched a three-year <a href="/wiki/Special_Campaign_to_Crack_Down_on_Organized_Crime_and_Eliminate_Evil" title="Special Campaign to Crack Down on Organized Crime and Eliminate Evil">Special Campaign to Crack Down on Organized Crime and Eliminate Evil</a> that lasted until 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-:04_123-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:04-123"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>120<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> After the special campaign exposed problems in the legal system, the CCP announced a campaign to <a href="/wiki/Education_and_Rectification_of_the_Political_and_Legal_Teams" title="Education and Rectification of the Political and Legal Teams">educate and rectify the political and legal teams</a> in July 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-:022_124-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:022-124"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>121<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>122<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Xi has overseen significant reforms of the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (CCDI), CCP's highest <a href="/wiki/Internal_control" title="Internal control">internal control</a> institution.<sup id="cite_ref-xinj_126-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-xinj-126"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>123<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He and CCDI Secretary Wang Qishan further institutionalized CCDI's independence from the day-to-day operations of the CCP, improving its ability to function as a <i>bona fide</i> control body.<sup id="cite_ref-xinj_126-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-xinj-126"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>123<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> According to <i>The Wall Street Journal</i>, anti-corruption punishment to officials at or above the vice ministerial level need approval from Xi.<sup id="cite_ref-Chin-2021_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chin-2021-127"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>124<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <i>The Wall Street Journal</i> said that when he wants to neutralize a political rival, he asks inspectors to prepare pages of evidence. It also said he authorizes investigations on close associates of a high-ranking politician, to replace them with his proteges and puts rivals in less important positions to separate them from their political bases. Reportedly, these tactics have even been used against Wang Qishan, Xi's close friend.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>125<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>According to <a href="/wiki/Sinologist" class="mw-redirect" title="Sinologist">sinologist</a> <a href="/wiki/Wang_Gungwu" title="Wang Gungwu">Wang Gungwu</a>, Xi inherited a party that was faced with pervasive corruption.<sup id="cite_ref-Jesus_College-2021_129-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jesus_College-2021-129"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>126<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>127<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi believed corruption at the higher levels of the CCP put the party and country at risk of collapse.<sup id="cite_ref-Jesus_College-2021_129-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jesus_College-2021-129"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>126<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Wang adds that Xi has a belief that only the CCP is capable of governing China, and that its collapse would be disastrous for the Chinese people. Xi and the new generational leaders reacted by launching the anti-corruption campaign to eliminate corruption at the higher levels of the government.<sup id="cite_ref-Jesus_College-2021_129-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jesus_College-2021-129"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>126<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Censorship">Censorship</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Censorship_in_China" title="Censorship in China">Censorship in China</a> and <a href="/wiki/Internet_censorship_in_China" title="Internet censorship in China">Internet censorship in China</a></div>
<p>Since Xi became general secretary, censorship has stepped up.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>128<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>129<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Chairing the 2018 China Cyberspace Governance Conference, Xi committed to "fiercely crack down on criminal offenses including hacking, telecom fraud, and violation of citizens' privacy."<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>130<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> During a visit to Chinese state media, Xi stated that "<a href="/wiki/Party_media_takes_the_party%27s_last_name" title="Party media takes the party&#39;s last name">party and government-owned media must hold the family name of the party</a>" and that the state media "must embody the party's will, safeguard the party's authority".<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>131<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>His administration has overseen more Internet restrictions imposed, and is described as being "stricter across the board" on speech than previous administrations.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>132<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi has taken a strong stand to control internet usage inside China, including <a href="/wiki/Google" title="Google">Google</a> and <a href="/wiki/Facebook" title="Facebook">Facebook</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBougon2018157–65_136-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBougon2018157–65-136"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>133<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> advocating Internet censorship under the concept of <a href="/wiki/Network_sovereignty" title="Network sovereignty">internet sovereignty</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>134<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>135<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Censorship_of_Wikipedia" title="Censorship of Wikipedia">censorship of Wikipedia</a> has been stringent; in April 2019, all versions of Wikipedia were blocked.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>136<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Likewise, the situation for users of <a href="/wiki/Sina_Weibo" class="mw-redirect" title="Sina Weibo">Weibo</a> has been described as a change from fearing one's account would be deleted, to fear of arrest.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>137<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>A law enacted in 2013 authorized a three-year prison term for bloggers who shared more than 500 times any content considered "defamatory".<sup id="cite_ref-Grigg2_141-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Grigg2-141"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>138<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The State Internet Information Department summoned influential bloggers to a seminar to instruct them to avoid writing about politics, the CCP, or making statements contradicting official narratives. Many bloggers stopped writing about controversial topics, and Weibo went into decline, with much of its readership shifting to <a href="/wiki/WeChat" title="WeChat">WeChat</a> users speaking to limited social circles.<sup id="cite_ref-Grigg2_141-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Grigg2-141"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>138<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Consolidation_of_power">Consolidation of power</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/New_Zhijiang_Army" class="mw-redirect" title="New Zhijiang Army">New Zhijiang Army</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fujian_clique" class="mw-redirect" title="Fujian clique">Fujian clique</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:%E6%8A%97%E6%88%98%E8%83%9C%E5%88%A970%E5%91%A8%E5%B9%B4%E9%98%85%E5%85%B5%E6%BC%94%E7%BB%83.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/%E6%8A%97%E6%88%98%E8%83%9C%E5%88%A970%E5%91%A8%E5%B9%B4%E9%98%85%E5%85%B5%E6%BC%94%E7%BB%83.jpg/250px-%E6%8A%97%E6%88%98%E8%83%9C%E5%88%A970%E5%91%A8%E5%B9%B4%E9%98%85%E5%85%B5%E6%BC%94%E7%BB%83.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="131" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/%E6%8A%97%E6%88%98%E8%83%9C%E5%88%A970%E5%91%A8%E5%B9%B4%E9%98%85%E5%85%B5%E6%BC%94%E7%BB%83.jpg/500px-%E6%8A%97%E6%88%98%E8%83%9C%E5%88%A970%E5%91%A8%E5%B9%B4%E9%98%85%E5%85%B5%E6%BC%94%E7%BB%83.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1155" data-file-height="605" /></a><figcaption>Portrait of Xi in Beijing, September 2015</figcaption></figure>
<p>Political observers have called Xi the most powerful Chinese leader since Mao Zedong, especially since the ending of presidential two-term limits in 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-PhillipsGuardian2_142-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PhillipsGuardian2-142"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>139<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>140<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>141<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>142<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi has departed from the <a href="/wiki/Collective_leadership" title="Collective leadership">collective leadership</a> practices of post-Mao predecessors. He has centralised his power and created working groups with himself at the head to subvert government bureaucracy, making himself become the unmistakable central figure of the administration.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>143<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In the opinion of at least one political scientist, Xi "has surrounded himself with cadres he met while stationed on the coast, Fujian and <a href="/wiki/Shanghai" title="Shanghai">Shanghai</a> and in Zhejiang."<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>144<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Observers have said that Xi has seriously diluted the influence of the once-dominant "<a href="/wiki/Tuanpai" title="Tuanpai">Tuanpai</a>," also called the Youth League Faction, which were CCP officials who rose through the Communist Youth League (CYLC).<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>145<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He criticized the cadres of the CYLC, saying that [these cadres] can't talk about science, literature and art, work or life [with young people]. All they can do is just repeat the same old bureaucratic, stereotypical talk."<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>146<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In 2018, the <a href="/wiki/National_People%27s_Congress" title="National People&#39;s Congress">National People's Congress</a> (NPC) passed <a href="/wiki/2018_amendment_to_the_Constitution_of_China" title="2018 amendment to the Constitution of China">constitutional amendments</a> including removal of term limits for the president and vice president, the creation of a <a href="/wiki/National_Supervisory_Commission" title="National Supervisory Commission">National Supervisory Commission</a>, as well as enhancing the central role of the CCP.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>147<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>148<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi was reappointed as president, now without term limits,<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>149<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>150<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> while Li Keqiang was reappointed premier.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>151<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> According to the <i><a href="/wiki/Financial_Times" title="Financial Times">Financial Times</a></i>, Xi expressed his views of constitutional amendment at meetings with Chinese officials and foreign dignitaries. Xi explained the decision in terms of needing to align two more powerful posts—general secretary of the CCP and chairman of the CMC—which have no term limits. However, Xi did not say whether he intended to be party general secretary, CMC chairman and state president, for three or more terms.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>152<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>
In its sixth plenary session in November 2021, CCP adopted a <a href="/wiki/Resolution_on_the_Major_Achievements_and_Historical_Experience_of_the_Party_over_the_Past_Century" title="Resolution on the Major Achievements and Historical Experience of the Party over the Past Century">historical resolution</a>, a kind of document that evaluated the party's history. This was the third of its kind after ones adopted by Mao Zedong and Deng Xiaoping.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>153<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>154<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In comparison with the other historical resolutions, Xi's one did not herald a major change in how the CCP evaluated its history.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>155<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> To accompany the historical resolution, the CCP promoted the terms <a href="/wiki/Two_Establishes" title="Two Establishes">Two Establishes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Two_Upholds" title="Two Upholds">Two Upholds</a>, calling the CCP to unite around and protect Xi's core status within the party.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>156<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></p><figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><span><video id="mwe_player_1" poster="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Xi_Jinping_leads_CPC_leadership_in_meeting_the_press.webm/250px--Xi_Jinping_leads_CPC_leadership_in_meeting_the_press.webm.jpg" controls="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/4/4d/Xi_Jinping_leads_CPC_leadership_in_meeting_the_press.webm/Xi_Jinping_leads_CPC_leadership_in_meeting_the_press.webm.240p.vp9.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&quot;vp9, opus&quot;" data-transcodekey="240p.vp9.webm" data-width="426" data-height="240" /><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/4/4d/Xi_Jinping_leads_CPC_leadership_in_meeting_the_press.webm/Xi_Jinping_leads_CPC_leadership_in_meeting_the_press.webm.360p.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&quot;vp8, vorbis&quot;" data-transcodekey="360p.webm" data-width="640" data-height="360" /><source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/4/4d/Xi_Jinping_leads_CPC_leadership_in_meeting_the_press.webm/Xi_Jinping_leads_CPC_leadership_in_meeting_the_press.webm.360p.vp9.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&quot;vp9, opus&quot;" data-transcodekey="360p.vp9.webm" data-width="640" data-height="360" /></video></span><figcaption>Xi Jinping and other members of the <a href="/wiki/20th_Politburo_Standing_Committee_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="20th Politburo Standing Committee of the Chinese Communist Party">20th Politburo Standing Committee</a> meeting the press, October 2022</figcaption></figure><p>The <a href="/wiki/20th_National_Congress_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="20th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party">20th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party</a>, held between 16 and 22 October 2022, has overseen amendments in the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Constitution of the Chinese Communist Party">CCP constitution</a> and the re-election of Xi as general secretary of the CCP and chairman of the CMC for a third term, with the overall result of the Congress being further strengthening of Xi's power.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>157<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi's re-election made him the first party leader since Mao Zedong to be chosen for a third term, though Deng Xiaoping ruled the country informally for a longer period.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>158<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The new Politburo Standing Committee elected just after the CCP Congress was filled almost completely with people close to Xi, with four out of the seven members of the previous PSC stepping down.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>159<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi was further re-elected as the PRC president and chairman of the PRC Central Military Commission on 10 March 2023 during the opening of the <a href="/wiki/14th_National_People%27s_Congress" title="14th National People&#39;s Congress">14th National People's Congress</a>, while Xi ally <a href="/wiki/Li_Qiang" title="Li Qiang">Li Qiang</a> succeeded Li Keqiang as the Premier.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>160<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Cult_of_personality">Cult of personality</h4></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping%27s_cult_of_personality" title="Xi Jinping&#39;s cult of personality">Xi Jinping's cult of personality</a></div>
<p>Xi has had a <a href="/wiki/Cult_of_personality" title="Cult of personality">cult of personality</a> constructed around himself since entering office<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>161<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>162<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> with books, cartoons, pop songs and dance routines honouring his rule.<sup id="cite_ref-PhilGuard12_166-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PhilGuard12-166"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>163<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Following Xi's ascension to the <a href="/wiki/Leadership_core" title="Leadership core">leadership core</a> of the CCP, he had been referred to as <i>Xi Dada</i> (<span lang="zh-Hans">习大大</span>, Uncle or Papa Xi),<sup id="cite_ref-PhilGuard12_166-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PhilGuard12-166"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>163<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>164<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> though this stopped in April 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>165<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The village of Liangjiahe, where Xi was sent to work, is decorated with propaganda and murals extolling the formative years of his life.<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>166<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Politburo_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Politburo of the Chinese Communist Party">CCP's Politburo</a> named Xi Jinping <i>lingxiu</i> (<span lang="zh-Hans">领袖</span>), a reverent term for "leader" and a title previously only given to Mao Zedong and his immediate successor <a href="/wiki/Hua_Guofeng" title="Hua Guofeng">Hua Guofeng</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>167<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>168<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>169<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He is also sometimes called the "pilot at the helm" (<span lang="zh-Hans">领航掌舵</span>).<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>170<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> On 25 December 2019, the Politburo officially named Xi as "People's Leader" (<span lang="zh-Hans">人民领袖</span>; <i><span lang="zh-Latn">rénmín lǐngxiù</span></i>), a title only Mao had held previously.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>171<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Economy_and_technology">Economy and technology</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_China" title="Economy of China">Economy of China</a></div><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping_Thought_on_Economy" title="Xi Jinping Thought on Economy">Xi Jinping Thought on Economy</a></div>
<p>Xi was initially seen as a market reformist,<sup id="cite_ref-Whyte-2021_175-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Whyte-2021-175"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>172<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and a central committee under him announced "market forces" would begin to play a "decisive" role in allocating resources.<sup id="cite_ref-brook2_176-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-brook2-176"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>173<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> This meant that the state would gradually reduce its involvement in the distribution of capital, and restructure <a href="/wiki/State-owned_enterprises_of_China" title="State-owned enterprises of China">state-owned enterprises</a> (SOEs) to allow further competition, potentially by attracting foreign and private sector players in industries previously highly regulated. This policy aimed to address the bloated state sector that had unduly profited from re-structuring by purchasing assets at below-market prices, assets no longer being used productively. Xi launched the <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Free-Trade_Zone" title="Shanghai Free-Trade Zone">Shanghai Free-Trade Zone</a> in 2013, which was seen as part of the economic reforms.<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>174<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> However, by 2017, Xi's promise of economic reforms was said to have stalled by experts.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>175<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Whyte-2021_175-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Whyte-2021-175"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>172<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2015, the <a href="/wiki/2015%E2%80%932016_Chinese_stock_market_turbulence" title="2015–2016 Chinese stock market turbulence">Chinese stock market bubble popped</a>, which led Xi to use state forces to fix it.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWong2023146_179-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWong2023146-179"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>176<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> From 2012 to 2022, the share of the market value of private sector firms in China's top listed companies increased from 10% to over 40%.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_180-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-180"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>177<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He has overseen the relaxation of restrictions on <a href="/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment" title="Foreign direct investment">foreign direct investment</a> (FDI) and increased cross-border holdings of stocks and bonds.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_180-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-180"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>177<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Xi has increased state control over the economy, voicing support for SOEs,<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>178<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Whyte-2021_175-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Whyte-2021-175"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>172<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> while also supporting the private sector.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>179<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> CCP control of SOEs has increased, while limited steps towards market liberalization, such as increasing mixed ownership of SOEs were undertaken.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPiekeHofman202248_183-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPiekeHofman202248-183"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>180<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Under Xi, "government guidance funds," public-private investment funds set up by or for government bodies, have raised more than $900 billion for early funding to companies that work in sectors the government deems as strategic.<sup id="cite_ref-Lockett-2022_184-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lockett-2022-184"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>181<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> His administration made it easier for banks to issue <a href="/wiki/Mortgage_loan" class="mw-redirect" title="Mortgage loan">mortgages</a>, increased foreign participation in the bond market, and increased the national currency <a href="/wiki/Renminbi" title="Renminbi">renminbi's</a> global role, helping it to join <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">IMF's</a> basket of <a href="/wiki/Special_drawing_rights" title="Special drawing rights">special drawing right</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>182<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2018, he promised to continue reforms but warned nobody "can dictate to the Chinese people."<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>183<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>China's economy has grown under Xi, doubling from $8.5 trillion in 2012 to $17.8 trillion in 2023,<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>184<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> while China's nominal GDP per capita surpassed the world average in 2021,<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>185<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> though growth has slowed from 7.9% in 2012 to 5.2% in 2023.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>186<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi has stressed the importance of "high-quality growth" rather than "inflated growth."<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>187<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He has stated China has abandoned a growth-at-all-costs strategy which Xi refers to as "GDP heroism."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMarquisQiao202222_191-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMarquisQiao202222-191"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>188<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Instead, Xi said other social issues such as environmental protection are important.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMarquisQiao202222_191-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMarquisQiao202222-191"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>188<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi has made eradicating extreme poverty through <a href="/wiki/Targeted_Poverty_Alleviation" title="Targeted Poverty Alleviation">targeted poverty alleviation</a> a key goal.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>189<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2015, he launched the <a href="/wiki/Battle_against_poverty" title="Battle against poverty">battle against poverty</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>190<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> which concluded by 2021, when Xi declared a "complete victory" over extreme poverty, saying nearly 100 million have been lifted out of poverty under his tenure, though some experts said China's <a href="/wiki/Poverty_threshold" title="Poverty threshold">poverty threshold</a> was lower than that of the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>191<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2020, premier Li Keqiang, citing the <a href="/wiki/National_Bureau_of_Statistics_of_China" title="National Bureau of Statistics of China">National Bureau of Statistics</a> (NBS) said that China still had 600 million people living with less than 1000 yuan ($140) a month, although <i>The Economist</i> said the methodology NBS used was flawed.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>192<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> When Xi took office in 2012, 54% of people in China were living on less than $6.85 per day, in 2021 this had fallen to 17%.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>193<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Xi has circulated a policy called <a href="/wiki/Dual_circulation" title="Dual circulation">dual circulation</a>, meaning reorienting the economy towards domestic consumption while remaining open to foreign trade and investment.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>194<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi has prioritised boosting <a href="/wiki/Productivity" title="Productivity">productivity</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>195<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi has attempted to reform the property sector to combat the steep increase in prices and cut the economy's dependence on it.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>196<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In the 19th CCP National Congress, Xi declared "<a href="/wiki/Houses_are_for_living,_not_for_speculation" title="Houses are for living, not for speculation">houses are for living, not for speculation</a>."<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>197<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2020, Xi's government formulated the "<a href="/wiki/Three_red_lines" title="Three red lines">three red lines</a>" policy that aimed to deleverage the heavily indebted property sector.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>198<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi has supported a <a href="/wiki/Property_tax" title="Property tax">property tax</a>, for which he has faced resistance from members of the CCP.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>199<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> His administration pursued a debt-deleveraging campaign, seeking to slow and cut the unsustainable amount of debt China has accrued during its growth.<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>200<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Since 2021, China has faced a <a href="/wiki/Chinese_property_sector_crisis_(2020%E2%80%93present)" title="Chinese property sector crisis (2020–present)">property sector crisis</a>, with decreasing house prices, shrinking of the real estate sector and bankruptcies of many property developers, partially as a result of Xi's efforts to decrease the sector's role in the Chinese economy.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>201<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Xi has heavily emphasized the role of advanced manufacturing and technology development to drive China's future economic growth.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>202<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi's administration has promoted <a href="/wiki/Made_in_China_2025" title="Made in China 2025">Made in China 2025</a> plan that aims to make China self-reliant in key technologies, although publicly China de-emphasised this plan due to the outbreak of a <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93United_States_trade_war" title="China–United States trade war">China–United States trade war</a>. Since the outbreak of the trade war in 2018, Xi has revived calls for "self-reliance," especially on technology.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>203<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Domestic spending on R&amp;D has significantly increased, surpassing the European Union (EU) and reaching a record $564 billion in 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-:8_207-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:8-207"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>204<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The Chinese government has supported technology companies like <a href="/wiki/Huawei" title="Huawei">Huawei</a> through grants, tax breaks, credit facilities and other assistance, enabling their rise, leading to US countermeasures.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>205<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2023, Xi put forward <a href="/wiki/New_productive_forces" title="New productive forces">new productive forces</a>, this refers to a new form of productive forces derived from continuous sci-tech breakthroughs and innovation that drive strategic emerging and future industries in a more intelligent <a href="/wiki/Information_Age" title="Information Age">information era</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-:02_209-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:02-209"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>206<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi has been involved in the development of <a href="/wiki/Xiong%27an" title="Xiong&#39;an">Xiong'an</a>, a <a href="/wiki/New_areas" title="New areas">new area</a> announced in 2017, planned to become a major metropolis near Beijing; the relocation aspect is estimated to last until 2035 while it is planned to developed into a "modern socialist city" by 2050.<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>207<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Under Xi, China made rapid advances in key technological areas, becoming a world leader in tech such as <a href="/wiki/Plug-in_electric_vehicles_in_China" title="Plug-in electric vehicles in China">electric vehicles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lithium_batteries_in_China" title="Lithium batteries in China">lithium batteries</a> and solar panels.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>208<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1224211176" /><div class="quotebox pullquote floatright" style="width:25em; ;">
<blockquote class="quotebox-quote left-aligned" style="">
<p>Common prosperity is an essential requirement of socialism and a key feature of Chinese-style modernization. The common prosperity we are pursuing is for all, affluence both in material and spiritual life, but not for a small portion nor for uniform egalitarianism.
</p>
</blockquote>
<div style="padding-bottom: 0; padding-top: 0.5em"><cite class="left-aligned" style="">— Xi Jinping during a speech in 2021<sup id="cite_ref-Caixin_Global-2021_212-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Caixin_Global-2021-212"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>209<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></cite></div>
</div>
<p>In 2020, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal" title="The Wall Street Journal">The Wall Street Journal</a></i> reported that Xi ordered a halt to <a href="/wiki/Ant_Group" title="Ant Group">Ant Group</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Initial_public_offering" title="Initial public offering">initial public offering</a> (IPO), in reaction to its founder <a href="/wiki/Jack_Ma" title="Jack Ma">Jack Ma</a> criticizing government regulation in finance.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>210<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi's administration has overseen a decrease in offshore IPOs by Chinese companies, with most Chinese IPOs taking place either in Shanghai or Shenzhen as of 2022<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Xi_Jinping&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, and has increasingly directed funding to IPOs of companies that works in sectors it deems as strategic, including electric vehicles, <a href="/wiki/Biotechnology_industry_in_China" title="Biotechnology industry in China">biotechnology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy_in_China" title="Renewable energy in China">renewable energy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_industry_in_China" title="Artificial intelligence industry in China">artificial intelligence</a>, <a href="/wiki/Semiconductor_industry_in_China" title="Semiconductor industry in China">semiconductors</a> and other high-technology manufacturing.<sup id="cite_ref-Lockett-2022_184-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lockett-2022-184"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>181<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Since 2021, Xi has promoted the term "<a href="/wiki/Common_prosperity" title="Common prosperity">common prosperity</a>," which he defined as an "essential requirement of socialism," described as affluence for all and said entailed reasonable adjustments to excess incomes.<sup id="cite_ref-Caixin_Global-2021_212-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Caixin_Global-2021-212"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>209<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>211<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Common prosperity has been used as the justification for <a href="/wiki/2020%E2%80%932021_Xi_Jinping_Administration_reform_spree" title="2020–2021 Xi Jinping Administration reform spree">large-scale crackdowns and regulations</a> towards the perceived "excesses" of several sectors, most prominently tech and tutoring industries.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>212<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Actions taken include fining large tech companies<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>213<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and passing laws such as the <a href="/wiki/Data_Security_Law_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Data Security Law of the People&#39;s Republic of China">Data Security Law</a>. China introduced severe restrictions on private tutoring companies, effectively destroying the whole industry.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>214<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi opened a <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Stock_Exchange" title="Beijing Stock Exchange">new stock exchange</a> in Beijing targeted for small and medium enterprises (SMEs).<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>215<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> There have been other cultural regulations including restrictions on minors playing video games and crackdowns on celebrity culture.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>216<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>217<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The push for common prosperity has also included salary and bonus cuts, especially across the financial sector,<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>218<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>219<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> as well as crackdowns on wealth flaunting.<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>220<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Reforms">Reforms</h3></div>
<p>In November 2013, at the conclusion of the Third Plenum of the 18th Central Committee, the Communist Party delivered a far-reaching reform agenda that alluded to changes in both economic and social policy. Xi signaled at the plenum that he was consolidating control of the massive internal security organization that was formerly the domain of Zhou Yongkang.<sup id="cite_ref-brook2_176-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-brook2-176"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>173<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> A new National Security Commission was formed with Xi at its helm, which commentators have said would help Xi consolidate over national security affairs.<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>221<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>222<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Central_Leading_Group_for_Comprehensively_Deepening_Reforms" class="mw-redirect" title="Central Leading Group for Comprehensively Deepening Reforms">Central Leading Group for Comprehensively Deepening Reforms</a>—another <i>ad hoc</i> policy coordination body led by Xi upgraded to a commission in 2018—was also formed to oversee the implementation of the reform agenda.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>223<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>224<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Termed "comprehensive deepening reforms" (<span lang="zh-Hans">全面深化改革</span>; <i><span lang="zh-Latn">quánmiàn shēnhuà gǎigé</span></i>), they were said to be the most significant since Deng Xiaoping's 1992 Southern Tour. The plenum also announced economic reforms and resolved to abolish the <i><a href="/wiki/Laogai" title="Laogai">laogai</a></i> system of "<a href="/wiki/Re-education_through_labor" title="Re-education through labor">re-education through labour</a>," which was largely seen as a blot on China's human rights record. The system has faced significant criticism for years from domestic critics and foreign observers.<sup id="cite_ref-brook2_176-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-brook2-176"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>173<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In January 2016, a <a href="/wiki/Two-child_policy" title="Two-child policy">two-child policy</a> replaced the <a href="/wiki/One-child_policy" title="One-child policy">one-child policy</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>225<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> which was in turn was replaced with a <a href="/wiki/Three-child_policy" title="Three-child policy">three-child policy</a> in May 2021.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>226<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In July 2021, all family size limits as well as penalties for exceeding them were removed.<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>227<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Political_reforms">Political reforms</h4></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Neoauthoritarianism_(China)" class="mw-redirect" title="Neoauthoritarianism (China)">Neoauthoritarianism (China)</a></div>
<p>Xi's administration taken a number of changes to the structure of the CCP and state bodies, especially in a large overhaul in 2018. Beginning in 2013, the CCP under Xi has created a series of Central Leading Groups: supra-ministerial steering committees, designed to bypass existing institutions when making decisions, and ostensibly make policy-making a more efficient process. Xi was also believed to have diluted the authority of premier Li Keqiang, taking authority over the economy which has generally been considered to be the domain of the premier.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>228<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>229<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>February 2014 oversaw the creation of the <a href="/wiki/Central_Cyberspace_Affairs_Commission" title="Central Cyberspace Affairs Commission">Central Leading Group for Cybersecurity and Informatization</a> with Xi as its leader. The State Internet Information Office (SIIO), previously under the <a href="/wiki/State_Council_Information_Office" title="State Council Information Office">State Council Information Office</a> (SCI), was transferred to the central leading group and renamed in English into the Cyberspace Administration of China.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>230<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> As part of managing the financial system, the <a href="/wiki/Financial_Stability_and_Development_Committee" title="Financial Stability and Development Committee">Financial Stability and Development Committee</a>, a State Council body, was established in 2017. Chaired by vice premier <a href="/wiki/Liu_He_(politician)" title="Liu He (politician)">Liu He</a> during its existence, the committee was disestablished by the newly established Central Financial Commission during the 2023 Party and state reforms.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>231<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi has increased the role of the <a href="/wiki/Central_Financial_and_Economic_Affairs_Commission" title="Central Financial and Economic Affairs Commission">Central Financial and Economic Affairs Commission</a> at the expense of the <a href="/wiki/State_Council_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" class="mw-redirect" title="State Council of the People&#39;s Republic of China">State Council</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>232<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>2018 has seen the <a href="/wiki/Deepening_the_reform_of_the_Party_and_state_institutions" title="Deepening the reform of the Party and state institutions">deepening the reform of the Party and state institutions</a>. In that year, several <a href="/wiki/Leading_Small_Group" title="Leading Small Group">central leading groups</a> including <a href="/wiki/Central_Comprehensively_Deepening_Reforms_Commission" title="Central Comprehensively Deepening Reforms Commission">reform</a>, cyberspace affairs, <a href="/wiki/Central_Financial_and_Economic_Affairs_Commission" title="Central Financial and Economic Affairs Commission">finance and economics</a>. and <a href="/wiki/Central_Foreign_Affairs_Commission" title="Central Foreign Affairs Commission">foreign affairs</a> were upgraded to commissions.<sup id="cite_ref-Buckley-2018_236-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Buckley-2018-236"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>233<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The powers of the Central Propaganda Department was strengthened, which now oversaw the newly established <a href="/wiki/China_Media_Group" title="China Media Group">China Media Group</a> (CMG).<sup id="cite_ref-Buckley-2018_236-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Buckley-2018-236"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>233<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Two State Council departments. one dealing with <a href="/wiki/Overseas_Chinese_Affairs_Office" title="Overseas Chinese Affairs Office">overseas Chinese</a>, and other one dealing with <a href="/wiki/State_Administration_for_Religious_Affairs" title="State Administration for Religious Affairs">religious affairs</a>, were merged into the <a href="/wiki/United_Front_Work_Department" title="United Front Work Department">United Front Work Department</a> while another commission dealing with <a href="/wiki/National_Ethnic_Affairs_Commission" title="National Ethnic Affairs Commission">ethnic affairs</a> was brought under formal UFWD leadership.<sup id="cite_ref-Buckley-2018_236-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Buckley-2018-236"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>233<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2020, all elections at all levels of the <a href="/wiki/System_of_people%27s_congress" title="System of people&#39;s congress">people's congress system</a> and NPC were mandated to adhere to the leadership of the CCP.<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>234<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>2023 has seen further reforms to the CCP and state bureaucracy called the <a href="/wiki/Plan_on_reforming_Party_and_state_institutions" title="Plan on reforming Party and state institutions">plan on reforming Party and state institutions</a>, which included the strengthening of Party control over the financial and technology domains.<sup id="cite_ref-:4_238-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-238"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>235<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> This included the creation of two CCP bodies for overseeing finance; the <a href="/wiki/Central_Financial_Commission" title="Central Financial Commission">Central Financial Commission</a> (CFC), as well as the revival of the <a href="/wiki/Central_Financial_Work_Commission" title="Central Financial Work Commission">Central Financial Work Commission</a> (CFWC) that was previously dissolved in 2002.<sup id="cite_ref-:4_238-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-238"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>235<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Additionally, a new CCP <a href="/wiki/Central_Science_and_Technology_Commission" title="Central Science and Technology Commission">Central Science and Technology Commission</a> would be established to broadly oversee the technology sector, while a newly created <a href="/wiki/Society_Work_Department" title="Society Work Department">Society Work Department</a> was tasked with CCP interactions with several sectors, including civic groups, chambers of commerce and industry groups, as well as handling public petition and grievance work.<sup id="cite_ref-:4_238-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-238"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>235<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Regulatory bodies saw large overhauls.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>236<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Several regulatory responsibilities were also transferred from the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Bank_of_China" title="People&#39;s Bank of China">People's Bank of China</a> (PBoC) to another regulatory body, while the PBoC reopened offices around the country that were closed in a previous reorganization.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>237<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2024, the CCP's role was strengthened further with the State Council regulations amended to add a clause about following CCP ideology and policies.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>238<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Legal_reforms">Legal reforms</h4></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping_Thought_on_the_Rule_of_Law" title="Xi Jinping Thought on the Rule of Law">Xi Jinping Thought on the Rule of Law</a></div><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1224211176" /><div class="quotebox pullquote floatright" style="width:25em; ;">
<blockquote class="quotebox-quote left-aligned" style="">
<p>Efforts should be made to enable the people to see that justice is served in every judicial case.
</p>
</blockquote>
<div style="padding-bottom: 0; padding-top: 0.5em"><cite class="left-aligned" style="">— Xi Jinping during a speech in November 2020<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>239<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></cite></div>
</div>
<p>The party under Xi announced a raft of <a href="/wiki/Law_reform" title="Law reform">legal reforms</a> at the Fourth Plenum held in the fall 2014, and he called for "<a href="/wiki/Rule_of_law_in_China" class="mw-redirect" title="Rule of law in China">Chinese socialistic rule of law</a>" immediately afterwards. The party aimed to reform the legal system, which had been perceived as ineffective at delivering justice and affected by corruption, local government interference and lack of constitutional oversight. The plenum, while emphasizing the absolute leadership of the party, also called for a greater role of the constitution in the affairs of state and a strengthening of the role of the National People's Congress Standing Committee in interpreting the constitution.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>240<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It also called for more transparency in legal proceedings, more involvement of ordinary citizens in the legislative process, and an overall "professionalization" of the legal workforce. The party also planned to institute cross-jurisdictional circuit legal tribunals as well as giving provinces consolidated administrative oversight over lower level legal resources, which is intended to reduce local government involvement in legal proceedings.<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>241<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Military_reforms">Military reforms</h4></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Modernization_of_the_People%27s_Liberation_Army" title="Modernization of the People&#39;s Liberation Army">Modernization of the People's Liberation Army</a>, <a href="/wiki/2015_People%27s_Republic_of_China_military_reform" class="mw-redirect" title="2015 People&#39;s Republic of China military reform">2015 People's Republic of China military reform</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping_Thought_on_Strengthening_the_Military" title="Xi Jinping Thought on Strengthening the Military">Xi Jinping Thought on Strengthening the Military</a></div><p>Since taking power in 2012, Xi has undertaken an overhaul of the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army" title="People&#39;s Liberation Army">People's Liberation Army</a>, including both political reform and its modernization.<sup id="cite_ref-Lague-2019_245-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lague-2019-245"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>242<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Military-civil_fusion" title="Military-civil fusion">Military-civil fusion</a> has advanced under Xi.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>243<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>244<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi has been active in his participation in military affairs, taking a direct hands-on approach to military reform. In addition to being the Chairman of the CMC and leader of the <a href="/wiki/Central_Leading_Group_for_Military_Reform" title="Central Leading Group for Military Reform">Central Leading Group for Military Reform</a> founded in 2014 to oversee comprehensive military reforms, Xi has delivered numerous high-profile pronouncements vowing to clean up malfeasance and complacency in the military. Xi has repeatedly warned that the depoliticization of the PLA from the CCP would lead to a collapse similar to that of the Soviet Union.<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>245<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi held the New Gutian Conference in 2014, gathering China's top military officers, re-emphasizing the principle of "the party has absolute control over the army" first established by Mao at the 1929 <a href="/wiki/Gutian_Congress" title="Gutian Congress">Gutian Congress</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>246<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1224211176" /></p><div class="quotebox pullquote floatright" style="width:25em; ;">
<blockquote class="quotebox-quote left-aligned" style="">
<p>In the USSR, where the military was depoliticized, separated from the party and nationalized, the party was disarmed. When the Soviet Union came to crisis point, a big party was gone just like that. Proportionally, the Soviet Communist Party had more members than we do, but nobody was man enough to stand up and resist.
</p>
</blockquote>
<div style="padding-bottom: 0; padding-top: 0.5em"><cite class="left-aligned" style="">— Xi Jinping during a speech<sup id="cite_ref-:12aa_250-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:12aa-250"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>247<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></cite></div>
</div>
<p>Xi announced a reduction of 300,000 troops from the PLA in 2015, bringing its size to 2 million troops. Xi described this as a gesture of peace, while analysts such as Rory Medcalf have said that the cut was done to reduce costs as well as part of PLA's modernization.<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>248<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2016, he reduced the number of <a href="/wiki/Theater_command" title="Theater command">theater commands of the PLA</a> from seven to five.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>249<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He has also abolished the four autonomous <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army_General_Political_Department" class="mw-redirect" title="People&#39;s Liberation Army General Political Department">general departments</a> of the PLA, replacing them with 15 agencies directly reporting to the CMC.<sup id="cite_ref-Lague-2019_245-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lague-2019-245"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>242<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Two new branches of the PLA were created under his reforms, the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army_Strategic_Support_Force" title="People&#39;s Liberation Army Strategic Support Force">Strategic Support Force</a><sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>250<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and the Joint Logistics Support Force.<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>251<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2018, the PAP was placed under the sole control of the CMC; the PAP was previously under the joint command of the CMC and the State Council through the Ministry of Public Security.<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>252<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 15">&#58;&#8202;15&#8202;</span></sup>
</p><p>On 21 April 2016, Xi was named <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Military_Command_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" class="mw-redirect" title="Supreme Military Command of the People&#39;s Republic of China">commander-in-chief</a> of the country's new Joint Operations Command Center of the PLA.<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>253<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>254<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Some analysts interpreted this move as an attempt to display strength and strong leadership and as being more "political than military."<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>255<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> According to Ni Lexiong, a military affairs expert, Xi "not only controls the military but also does it in an absolute manner, and that in wartime, he is ready to command personally."<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>256<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> According to a <a href="/wiki/University_of_California,_San_Diego" title="University of California, San Diego">University of California, San Diego</a> expert on Chinese military, Xi "has been able to take political control of the military to an extent that exceeds what Mao and Deng have done."<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>257<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Under Xi, <a href="/wiki/Military_budget_of_China" title="Military budget of China">China's official military budget</a> has more than doubled,<sup id="cite_ref-:8_207-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:8-207"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>204<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> reaching a record $246 billion in 2025.<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>258<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Though predating Xi, his administration has taken a more assertive stance towards maritime affairs, and has boosted CCP control over the maritime security forces.<sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>259<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army_Navy" title="People&#39;s Liberation Army Navy">PLA Navy</a> has grown rapidly under Xi, with China adding more warships, submarines, support ships and major amphibious vessels than the entire number of ships under the United Kingdom navy between 2014 and 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>260<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2017, China established the navy's first <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army_Support_Base_in_Djibouti" title="People&#39;s Liberation Army Support Base in Djibouti">overseas base in Djibouti</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>261<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi has also undertaken an expansion of China's nuclear arsenal, with him calling China to "establish a strong system of strategic deterrence." The <a href="/wiki/Federation_of_American_Scientists" title="Federation of American Scientists">Federation of American Scientists</a> (FAS) has estimated China's total amount of nuclear arsenals to be 410 in 2023, with the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Defense" title="United States Department of Defense">US Department of Defense</a> estimating that China's arsenal could reach 1,000 by 2030.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>262<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Foreign_policy">Foreign policy</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_policy_of_Xi_Jinping" title="Foreign policy of Xi Jinping">Foreign policy of Xi Jinping</a>, <a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping_Thought_on_Diplomacy" title="Xi Jinping Thought on Diplomacy">Xi Jinping Thought on Diplomacy</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_international_trips_made_by_Xi_Jinping" title="List of international trips made by Xi Jinping">List of international trips made by Xi Jinping</a></div><figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:President_Biden_met_with_Xi_Jinping_before_the_2022_G20_Bali_Summit.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/President_Biden_met_with_Xi_Jinping_before_the_2022_G20_Bali_Summit.jpg/250px-President_Biden_met_with_Xi_Jinping_before_the_2022_G20_Bali_Summit.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/President_Biden_met_with_Xi_Jinping_before_the_2022_G20_Bali_Summit.jpg/500px-President_Biden_met_with_Xi_Jinping_before_the_2022_G20_Bali_Summit.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1365" /></a><figcaption>Xi Jinping with US President <a href="/wiki/Joe_Biden" title="Joe Biden">Joe Biden</a> at the <a href="/wiki/2022_G20_Bali_summit" title="2022 G20 Bali summit">17th G20 in Bali</a>, November 2022</figcaption></figure> <figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:2017_G20_Hamburg_summit_leaders_group_photo.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/2017_G20_Hamburg_summit_leaders_group_photo.jpg/250px-2017_G20_Hamburg_summit_leaders_group_photo.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="154" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/2017_G20_Hamburg_summit_leaders_group_photo.jpg/500px-2017_G20_Hamburg_summit_leaders_group_photo.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1880" data-file-height="1160" /></a><figcaption>World leaders assemble for "family photo" at <a href="/wiki/2017_G20_Hamburg_summit" title="2017 G20 Hamburg summit">G20 summit</a> in Hamburg.</figcaption></figure><p>Xi has taken a harder line on security issues as well as foreign affairs, projecting a more <a href="/wiki/Chinese_nationalism" title="Chinese nationalism">nationalistic</a> and assertive China on the world stage.<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>263<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> His political program calls for a China more united and confident of its own value system and political structure.<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>264<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Foreign analysts and observers have frequently said that Xi's
