main foreign policy objective is to restore China's position on the global stage as a <a href="/wiki/Great_power" title="Great power">great power</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>265<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:12aa_250-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:12aa-250"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>247<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>266<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi advocates "baseline thinking" in China's foreign policy: setting explicit red lines that other countries must not cross.<sup id="cite_ref-Zhao-2023_270-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Zhao-2023-270"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>267<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In the Chinese perspective, these tough stances on baseline issues reduce strategic uncertainty, preventing other nations from misjudging China's positions or underestimating China's resolve in asserting what it perceives to be in its national interest.<sup id="cite_ref-Zhao-2023_270-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Zhao-2023-270"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>267<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi stated during the 20th CCP National Congress that he wanted to ensure China "leads the world in terms of composite national strength and international influence" by 2049.<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>268<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Xi has promoted <a href="/wiki/Major-country_diplomacy" title="Major-country diplomacy">major-country diplomacy</a>, stating that China is already a "big power" and breaking away from previous Chinese leaders who had a more precautious diplomacy.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>269<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He has adopted a hawkish foreign policy posture called "<a href="/wiki/Wolf_warrior_diplomacy" title="Wolf warrior diplomacy">wolf warrior diplomacy</a>,"<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>270<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> while his foreign policy thoughts are collectively known as <a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping_Thought_on_Diplomacy" title="Xi Jinping Thought on Diplomacy">Xi Jinping Thought on Diplomacy</a>."<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>271<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In October 2020, he said that "<a href="/wiki/The_East_is_rising_and_the_West_is_declining" title="The East is rising and the West is declining">the East is rising and the West is declining</a>", saying that the power of the Western world was in decline and their COVID-19 response was an example of this, and that China was entering a period of opportunity because of this.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>272<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi has frequently alluded to <a href="/wiki/Community_of_Common_Destiny" title="Community of Common Destiny">community with a shared future for mankind</a>, which Chinese diplomats have said doesn't imply an intention to change the international order,<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>273<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> but which foreign observers say China wants a new order that puts it more at the centre.<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>274<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Under Xi, China has, along with Russia, also focused on increasing relations with the <a href="/wiki/Global_North_and_Global_South" title="Global North and Global South">Global South</a> in order to blunt the effect of <a href="/wiki/International_sanctions_during_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="International sanctions during the Russian invasion of Ukraine">international sanctions</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>275<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Vladimir_Putin_and_Xi_Jinping_having_tea_at_the_garden_of_Zhongnanhai_(2024-05-16)_2.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Vladimir_Putin_and_Xi_Jinping_having_tea_at_the_garden_of_Zhongnanhai_%282024-05-16%29_2.jpg/250px-Vladimir_Putin_and_Xi_Jinping_having_tea_at_the_garden_of_Zhongnanhai_%282024-05-16%29_2.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="154" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Vladimir_Putin_and_Xi_Jinping_having_tea_at_the_garden_of_Zhongnanhai_%282024-05-16%29_2.jpg/500px-Vladimir_Putin_and_Xi_Jinping_having_tea_at_the_garden_of_Zhongnanhai_%282024-05-16%29_2.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1880" data-file-height="1160" /></a><figcaption>Xi having tea with <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a> in the garden of <a href="/wiki/Zhongnanhai" title="Zhongnanhai">Zhongnanhai</a> during Putin's visit to China in May 2024</figcaption></figure>
<p>Xi has put an emphasis on increasing China's "international discourse power" (<span lang="zh-Hans">国际话语权</span>) to create a more favorable global opinion of China in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>276<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In this pursuit, Xi has emphasised the need to "<a href="/wiki/Telling_China%27s_stories_well" title="Telling China&#39;s stories well">tell China's stories well</a>", meaning expanding China's external propaganda (<span lang="zh-Hans">外宣</span>) and communications.<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>277<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi has expanded the focus and scope of the <a href="/wiki/United_front_(China)" title="United front (China)">united front</a>, which aims to consolidate support for CCP in non-CCP elements both inside and outside China, and has accordingly expanded the United Front Work Department.<sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>278<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi has unveiled the <a href="/wiki/Global_Development_Initiative" title="Global Development Initiative">Global Development Initiative</a> (GDI), the <a href="/wiki/Global_Security_Initiative" title="Global Security Initiative">Global Security Initiative</a> (GSI), and the <a href="/wiki/Global_Civilization_Initiative" title="Global Civilization Initiative">Global Civilisation Initiative</a> (GCI), in 2021, 2022 and 2023, respectively, aiming to increase China's influence in the international order.<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>279<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>280<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:12_284-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:12-284"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>281<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>During the Xi administration, China seeks to shape international norms and rules in emerging policy areas where China has an advantage as an early participant.<sup id="cite_ref-:Tsang&amp;Cheung_285-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:Tsang&amp;Cheung-285"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>282<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 188">&#58;&#8202;188&#8202;</span></sup> Xi describes such areas as "new frontiers," and they include policy areas such as space, deep sea, polar regions, the Internet, nuclear safety, anticorruption, and climate change.<sup id="cite_ref-:Tsang&amp;Cheung_285-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:Tsang&amp;Cheung-285"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>282<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 188">&#58;&#8202;188&#8202;</span></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Africa">Africa</h4></div>
<p>During Xi's administration, China has maintained cordial relationships with each Africa government except <a href="/wiki/Eswatini" title="Eswatini">Eswatini</a>, which recognizes Taiwan but not the PRC.<sup id="cite_ref-:2_286-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-286"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>283<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Under Xi, China has cut back lending to Africa after fears that African countries couldn't repay their debts to China.<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>284<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi has also promised that China would write off debts of some African countries.<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>285<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Asia">Asia</h4></div>
<p>Under Xi, China initially took a more critical stance on North Korea due to <a href="/wiki/North_Korea_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="North Korea and weapons of mass destruction">its nuclear tests</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-chengli232_289-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-chengli232-289"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>286<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> However, starting in 2018, the relations started to improve due to <a href="/wiki/Kim%E2%80%93Xi_meetings" title="Kim–Xi meetings">meetings between Xi and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un.</a><sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>287<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi has initially improved relationships with South Korea,<sup id="cite_ref-chengli23_291-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-chengli23-291"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>288<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and the two countries signed a <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93South_Korea_Free_Trade_Agreement" title="China–South Korea Free Trade Agreement">free-trade agreement</a> in December 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-:22_292-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:22-292"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>289<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Starting in 2017, China's relationship with South Korea soured over the <a href="/wiki/Terminal_High_Altitude_Area_Defense" title="Terminal High Altitude Area Defense">Terminal High Altitude Area Defence</a> (THAAD), a missile defense system, purchase of the latter, but improved after South Korea halted purchase of the THAAD.<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>290<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> China–Japan relations have initially soured under Xi's administration; the most thorny issue between the two countries remains the dispute over the <a href="/wiki/Senkaku_islands" class="mw-redirect" title="Senkaku islands">Senkaku islands</a>, which China calls Diaoyu.<sup id="cite_ref-osawa22_294-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-osawa22-294"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>291<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> However, the relations later started to improve, with Xi being invited to visit in 2020,<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>292<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> though the trip was later delayed due to the COVID-19 pandemic.<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>293<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Since Xi came to power, China has been rapidly building and militarizing islands in the South China Sea, a decision <i><a href="/wiki/Study_Times" title="Study Times">Study Times</a></i> of the <a href="/wiki/Central_Party_School_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" class="mw-redirect" title="Central Party School of the Chinese Communist Party">Central Party School of the Chinese Communist Party</a> said was personally taken by Xi.<sup id="cite_ref-Liu-2009_297-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Liu-2009-297"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>294<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Relations between China and India had ups and downs under Xi, later deteriorating due to various factors. The two countries had a <a href="/wiki/2013_Depsang_standoff" title="2013 Depsang standoff">standoff in Depsang</a> in 2013,<sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>295<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/2017_China%E2%80%93India_border_standoff" title="2017 China–India border standoff">again had a standoff</a> over a Chinese construction of a road in <a href="/wiki/Doklam" title="Doklam">Doklam</a>, a territory both claimed by <a href="/wiki/Bhutan" title="Bhutan">Bhutan</a>, India's ally, and China, in 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>296<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The most serious crisis in the relationship came when the two countries had a <a href="/wiki/2020%E2%80%932021_China%E2%80%93India_skirmishes" title="2020–2021 China–India skirmishes">deadly clash in 2020</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Line_of_Actual_Control" title="Line of Actual Control">Line of Actual Control</a>, leaving some soldiers dead.<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>297<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>298<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> While China has historically been wary of getting closer to the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a> countries, Xi has changed this approach, getting closer to both Iran and Saudi Arabia.<sup id="cite_ref-Vohra-2022_302-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vohra-2022-302"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>299<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Europe">Europe</h4></div>
<p>China's efforts under Xi has been for the European Union (EU) to stay in a neutral position in their contest with the U.S.<sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>300<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> China and the EU announced the <a href="/wiki/Comprehensive_Agreement_on_Investment" title="Comprehensive Agreement on Investment">Comprehensive Agreement on Investment</a> (CAI) in 2020, although the deal was later frozen due to mutual sanctions over Xinjiang.<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>301<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi has cultivated <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93Russia_relations" title="China–Russia relations">stronger relations with Russia</a>, particularly in the wake of the <a href="/wiki/2014_pro-Russian_unrest_in_Ukraine" title="2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine">Ukraine crisis</a> of 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-russia222_305-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-russia222-305"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>302<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="Russian invasion of Ukraine">Russian invasion of Ukraine</a>, Xi expressed opposition to <a href="/wiki/International_sanctions_during_the_Russo-Ukrainian_War" title="International sanctions during the Russo-Ukrainian War">sanctions against Russia</a><sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>303<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and asserted China's <a href="/wiki/China_and_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine" title="China and the Russian invasion of Ukraine">support for Russia</a> on issues of sovereignty and security, but also said China is committed to respecting "the territorial integrity of all countries",<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>304<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> while China has cast itself as a neutral party.<sup id="cite_ref-Xi-Putin_308-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Xi-Putin-308"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>305<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="United_States">United States</h4></div>
<p>Xi has called China–United States relations in the contemporary world a "new type of great-power relations", a phrase the <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Barack_Obama" title="Presidency of Barack Obama">Obama administration</a> had been reluctant to embrace.<sup id="cite_ref-nikkei2_309-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nikkei2-309"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>306<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi has indirectly spoken out critically on the U.S. "strategic pivot" to Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-blan2_310-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-blan2-310"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>307<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Relations with the U.S. soured after Donald Trump became president in 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>308<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Since 2018, U.S. and China have been engaged in an escalating trade war.<sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>309<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2020, the relations further deteriorated due to the COVID-19 pandemic.<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>310<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="National_security">National security</h3></div>
<p>Xi has devoted a large amount of work towards national security, calling for a "<a href="/wiki/Holistic_national_security" title="Holistic national security">holistic national security architecture</a>" that encompasses "all aspects of the work of the party and the country."<sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>311<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He introduced the holistic security concept in 2014, which he defined as taking "the security of the people as compass, political security as its roots, economic security as its pillar, military security and cultural security as its protections, and that relies on the promotion of international security."<sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>312<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 3">&#58;&#8202;3&#8202;</span></sup> During a private talk with U.S. president Obama and vice president Biden, he said that China had been a target of "<a href="/wiki/Colour_revolution" title="Colour revolution">colour revolutions</a>," foreshadowing his focus on national security.<sup id="cite_ref-Buckley-2022_316-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Buckley-2022-316"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>313<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Since its creation by Xi, the National Security Commission has established local security committees, focusing on dissent.<sup id="cite_ref-Buckley-2022_316-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Buckley-2022-316"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>313<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In the name of national security, Xi's government has passed numerous laws including a <a href="/wiki/Counterespionage_Law_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Counterespionage Law of the People&#39;s Republic of China">counterespionage law</a> in 2014,<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>314<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/National_Security_Law_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="National Security Law of the People&#39;s Republic of China">national security</a><sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>315<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and a <a href="/wiki/Counterterrorism_Law_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Counterterrorism Law of the People&#39;s Republic of China">counterterrorism law</a> in 2015,<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>316<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> a <a href="/wiki/Cybersecurity_Law_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Cybersecurity Law of the People&#39;s Republic of China">cybersecurity law</a><sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>317<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and a law restricting foreign <a href="/wiki/Non-governmental_organization" title="Non-governmental organization">NGOs</a> in 2016,<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>318<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> a <a href="/wiki/National_Intelligence_Law_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="National Intelligence Law of the People&#39;s Republic of China">national intelligence law</a> in 2017,<sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>319<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and a data security law in 2021.<sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>320<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Under Xi, <a href="/wiki/Mass_surveillance_in_China" title="Mass surveillance in China">China's mass surveillance network</a> has dramatically grown, with comprehensive profiles being built for each citizen.<sup id="cite_ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>321<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Hong_Kong">Hong Kong</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Conservatism_in_Hong_Kong#National_security_law_and_autocratisation" title="Conservatism in Hong Kong">Conservatism in Hong Kong §&#160;National security law and autocratisation</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:2019-10-01_Demonstration_Hong_Kong_11.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/2019-10-01_Demonstration_Hong_Kong_11.jpg/250px-2019-10-01_Demonstration_Hong_Kong_11.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="141" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/2019-10-01_Demonstration_Hong_Kong_11.jpg/500px-2019-10-01_Demonstration_Hong_Kong_11.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="3840" data-file-height="2160" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/2019%E2%80%9320_Hong_Kong_protests" class="mw-redirect" title="2019–20 Hong Kong protests">Hong Kong protesters</a> throw eggs at Xi Jinping's portrait on <a href="/wiki/National_Day_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="National Day of the People&#39;s Republic of China">National Day</a>.</figcaption></figure><p>During his leadership, Xi has supported and pursued a greater political and economic integration of <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a> to mainland China, including through projects such as the <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong%E2%80%93Zhuhai%E2%80%93Macau_Bridge" title="Hong Kong–Zhuhai–Macau Bridge">Hong Kong–Zhuhai–Macau Bridge</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Bland-2018_325-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bland-2018-325"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>322<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He has pushed for the <a href="/wiki/Guangdong%E2%80%93Hong_Kong%E2%80%93Macao_Greater_Bay_Area" title="Guangdong–Hong Kong–Macao Greater Bay Area">Greater Bay Area</a> project, which aims to integrate Hong Kong, Macau, and nine other cities in Guangdong.<sup id="cite_ref-:7_326-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:7-326"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>323<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Bland-2018_325-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bland-2018-325"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>322<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi's integration efforts have led to decreased freedoms and the weakening of Hong Kong's distinct identity from mainland China.<sup id="cite_ref-:7_326-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:7-326"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>323<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>324<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Many of the views held by the central government and eventually implemented in Hong Kong were outlined in a white paper published by the State Council in 2014 named <i><a href="/wiki/The_Practice_of_the_%27One_Country,_Two_Systems%27_Policy_in_the_Hong_Kong_Special_Administrative_Region" title="The Practice of the &#39;One Country, Two Systems&#39; Policy in the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region">The Practice of the 'One Country, Two Systems' Policy in the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region</a></i>, which outlined that the China's central government has "comprehensive jurisdiction" over Hong Kong.<sup id="cite_ref-Buckley-2021b_328-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Buckley-2021b-328"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>325<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Under Xi, the Chinese government also declared the <a href="/wiki/Sino-British_Joint_Declaration" title="Sino-British Joint Declaration">Sino-British Joint Declaration</a> to be legally void.<sup id="cite_ref-Buckley-2021b_328-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Buckley-2021b-328"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>325<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In August 2014, the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress (NPCSC) made a <a href="/wiki/2014_NPCSC_Decision_on_Hong_Kong" title="2014 NPCSC Decision on Hong Kong">decision</a> allowing universal suffrage for the <a href="/wiki/2017_Hong_Kong_Chief_Executive_election" title="2017 Hong Kong Chief Executive election">2017 election</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Chief_Executive_of_Hong_Kong" title="Chief Executive of Hong Kong">chief executive of Hong Kong</a>, also requiring the candidates to "love the country, and love Hong Kong," as well as other measures that ensured the Chinese leadership would be the ultimate decision-maker on the selection, leading to <a href="/wiki/2014_Hong_Kong_protests" title="2014 Hong Kong protests">protests</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>326<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and the eventual rejection of the reform bill in the Legislative Council due to a walk-out by the <a href="/wiki/Pro-Beijing_camp_(Hong_Kong)" title="Pro-Beijing camp (Hong Kong)">pro-Beijing camp</a> to delay to vote.<sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>327<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In the 2017 chief executive election, <a href="/wiki/Carrie_Lam" title="Carrie Lam">Carrie Lam</a> was victorious, reportedly with the endorsement of the CCP Politburo.<sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>328<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>
Xi has supported the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Hong_Kong" title="Government of Hong Kong">Hong Kong Government</a> and Carrie Lam against the protesters in the <a href="/wiki/2019%E2%80%932020_Hong_Kong_protests" title="2019–2020 Hong Kong protests">2019–2020 Hong Kong protests</a>, which broke out after a <a href="/wiki/2019_Hong_Kong_extradition_bill" title="2019 Hong Kong extradition bill">proposed bill</a> that would allow extraditions to China.<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>329<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He has defended the <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong_Police_Force" title="Hong Kong Police Force">Hong Kong police's</a> use of force, saying that "We sternly support the Hong Kong police to take forceful actions in enforcing the law, and the Hong Kong judiciary to punish in accordance with the law those who have committed violent crimes."<sup id="cite_ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>330<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> While visiting <a href="/wiki/Macau" title="Macau">Macau</a> on 20 December 2019 as part of the 20th anniversary of its return to China, Xi warned of foreign forces interfering in Hong Kong and Macau,<sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>331<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> while also hinting that Macau could be a model for Hong Kong to follow.<sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>332<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></p><figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:%E5%BA%86%E7%A5%9D%E9%A6%99%E6%B8%AF%E5%9B%9E%E5%BD%92%E7%A5%96%E5%9B%BD25%E5%91%A8%E5%B9%B4%E5%A4%A7%E4%BC%9A%E6%9A%A8%E9%A6%99%E6%B8%AF%E7%89%B9%E5%88%AB%E8%A1%8C%E6%94%BF%E5%8C%BA%E7%AC%AC%E5%85%AD%E5%B1%8A%E6%94%BF%E5%BA%9C%E5%B0%B1%E8%81%8C%E5%85%B8%E7%A4%BC_20220701-4.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/%E5%BA%86%E7%A5%9D%E9%A6%99%E6%B8%AF%E5%9B%9E%E5%BD%92%E7%A5%96%E5%9B%BD25%E5%91%A8%E5%B9%B4%E5%A4%A7%E4%BC%9A%E6%9A%A8%E9%A6%99%E6%B8%AF%E7%89%B9%E5%88%AB%E8%A1%8C%E6%94%BF%E5%8C%BA%E7%AC%AC%E5%85%AD%E5%B1%8A%E6%94%BF%E5%BA%9C%E5%B0%B1%E8%81%8C%E5%85%B8%E7%A4%BC_20220701-4.png/250px-%E5%BA%86%E7%A5%9D%E9%A6%99%E6%B8%AF%E5%9B%9E%E5%BD%92%E7%A5%96%E5%9B%BD25%E5%91%A8%E5%B9%B4%E5%A4%A7%E4%BC%9A%E6%9A%A8%E9%A6%99%E6%B8%AF%E7%89%B9%E5%88%AB%E8%A1%8C%E6%94%BF%E5%8C%BA%E7%AC%AC%E5%85%AD%E5%B1%8A%E6%94%BF%E5%BA%9C%E5%B0%B1%E8%81%8C%E5%85%B8%E7%A4%BC_20220701-4.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="140" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/%E5%BA%86%E7%A5%9D%E9%A6%99%E6%B8%AF%E5%9B%9E%E5%BD%92%E7%A5%96%E5%9B%BD25%E5%91%A8%E5%B9%B4%E5%A4%A7%E4%BC%9A%E6%9A%A8%E9%A6%99%E6%B8%AF%E7%89%B9%E5%88%AB%E8%A1%8C%E6%94%BF%E5%8C%BA%E7%AC%AC%E5%85%AD%E5%B1%8A%E6%94%BF%E5%BA%9C%E5%B0%B1%E8%81%8C%E5%85%B8%E7%A4%BC_20220701-4.png/500px-%E5%BA%86%E7%A5%9D%E9%A6%99%E6%B8%AF%E5%9B%9E%E5%BD%92%E7%A5%96%E5%9B%BD25%E5%91%A8%E5%B9%B4%E5%A4%A7%E4%BC%9A%E6%9A%A8%E9%A6%99%E6%B8%AF%E7%89%B9%E5%88%AB%E8%A1%8C%E6%94%BF%E5%8C%BA%E7%AC%AC%E5%85%AD%E5%B1%8A%E6%94%BF%E5%BA%9C%E5%B0%B1%E8%81%8C%E5%85%B8%E7%A4%BC_20220701-4.png 1.5x" data-file-width="1058" data-file-height="593" /></a><figcaption>Xi swearing in John Lee as chief executive during the 25th anniversary of Hong Kong's return to China</figcaption></figure>
<p>In 2020, the NPCSC passed a <a href="/wiki/2020_Hong_Kong_national_security_law" title="2020 Hong Kong national security law">national security law</a> in Hong Kong that dramatically expanded government clampdown over the opposition in the city; amongst the measures were the dramatic restriction on political opposition and the creation of a <a href="/wiki/Office_for_Safeguarding_National_Security_of_the_CPG_in_the_HKSAR" class="mw-redirect" title="Office for Safeguarding National Security of the CPG in the HKSAR">central government office</a> outside Hong Kong jurisdiction to oversee the enforcement of the law.<sup id="cite_ref-Buckley-2021b_328-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Buckley-2021b-328"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>325<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> This was seen as the culmination of a long-term project under Xi to further closely integrate Hong Kong with the mainland.<sup id="cite_ref-Buckley-2021b_328-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Buckley-2021b-328"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>325<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi visited Hong Kong as president in 2017 and 2022, in the 20th and 25th anniversary of the handover of Hong Kong respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>333<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/2022_Xi_Jinping_visit_to_Hong_Kong" title="2022 Xi Jinping visit to Hong Kong">his 2022 visit</a>, he swore in <a href="/wiki/John_Lee_Ka-chiu" title="John Lee Ka-chiu">John Lee</a> as chief executive, a former police officer that was backed by the Chinese government to expand control over the city.<sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>334<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-338" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-338"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>335<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Taiwan">Taiwan</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Cross-Strait_relations" class="mw-redirect" title="Cross-Strait relations">Cross-Strait relations</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ma%E2%80%93Xi_meeting" class="mw-redirect" title="Ma–Xi meeting">Ma–Xi meeting</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:2015_Ma%E2%80%93Xi_Meeting_08.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/2015_Ma%E2%80%93Xi_Meeting_08.jpg/250px-2015_Ma%E2%80%93Xi_Meeting_08.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/2015_Ma%E2%80%93Xi_Meeting_08.jpg/500px-2015_Ma%E2%80%93Xi_Meeting_08.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="5760" data-file-height="3840" /></a><figcaption>Xi Jinping met with then-Taiwanese president <a href="/wiki/Ma_Ying-jeou" title="Ma Ying-jeou">Ma Ying-jeou</a> in November 2015 in their capacity as the leader of mainland China and Taiwan respectively.</figcaption></figure>
<p>In November 2015, Xi met with Taiwanese president <a href="/wiki/Ma_Ying-jeou" title="Ma Ying-jeou">Ma Ying-jeou</a>, which marked the first time the political leaders of both sides of the <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Strait" title="Taiwan Strait">Taiwan Strait</a> have met since the end of the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Civil_War" title="Chinese Civil War">Chinese Civil War</a> in mainland China in 1950.<sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>336<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi said that China and Taiwan are "<a href="/wiki/Zhonghua_minzu" title="Zhonghua minzu">one family</a>" that cannot be pulled apart.<sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>337<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> However, the relations started deteriorating after <a href="/wiki/Tsai_Ing-wen" title="Tsai Ing-wen">Tsai Ing-wen</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Progressive_Party" title="Democratic Progressive Party">Democratic Progressive Party</a> (DPP) won the <a href="/wiki/2016_Taiwanese_presidential_election" title="2016 Taiwanese presidential election">presidential elections in 2016</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>338<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In the 19th Party Congress held in 2017, Xi reaffirmed six of the nine principles that had been affirmed continuously since the 16th Party Congress in 2002, with the notable exception of "Placing hopes on the <a href="/wiki/People_of_Taiwan" class="mw-redirect" title="People of Taiwan">Taiwan people</a> as a force to help bring about <a href="/wiki/Chinese_unification" title="Chinese unification">unification</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-Brookings_R.C._Bush2_342-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brookings_R.C._Bush2-342"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>339<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/Brookings_Institution" title="Brookings Institution">Brookings Institution</a>, Xi used stronger language on potential <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_independence_movement" title="Taiwan independence movement">Taiwan independence</a> than his predecessors towards previous DPP governments in Taiwan. Xi said that "we will never allow any person, any organisation, or any political party to split any part of the Chinese territory from China at any time at any form."<sup id="cite_ref-Brookings_R.C._Bush2_342-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brookings_R.C._Bush2-342"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>339<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In January 2019, Xi Jinping called on Taiwan to reject its formal independence from China, saying: "We make no promise to renounce the use of force and reserve the option of taking all necessary means." Those options, he said, could be used against "external interference". Xi also said that they "are willing to create broad space for peaceful reunification, but will leave no room for any form of separatist activities."<sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>340<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-344" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-344"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>341<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> President Tsai responded to the speech by saying Taiwan would not accept a <a href="/wiki/One_country,_two_systems" title="One country, two systems">one country, two systems</a> arrangement with the mainland, while stressing the need for all cross-strait negotiations to be on a government-to-government basis.<sup id="cite_ref-345" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-345"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>342<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Human_rights">Human rights</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_China" title="Human rights in China">Human rights in China</a> and <a href="/wiki/Antireligious_campaigns_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" class="mw-redirect" title="Antireligious campaigns of the Chinese Communist Party">Antireligious campaigns of the Chinese Communist Party</a></div>
<p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch" title="Human Rights Watch">Human Rights Watch</a>, Xi has "started a broad and sustained offensive on human rights" since he became leader in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>343<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The HRW also said that repression in China is "at its worst level since the Tiananmen Square massacre."<sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>344<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Since taking power, Xi has cracked down on grassroots activism, with hundreds being detained.<sup id="cite_ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>345<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He presided over the <a href="/wiki/709_crackdown" title="709 crackdown">709 crackdown</a> on 9 July 2015, which saw more than 200 lawyers, legal assistants and human rights activists being detained.<sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>346<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> His term has seen the arrest and imprisonment of activists such as <a href="/wiki/Xu_Zhiyong" title="Xu Zhiyong">Xu Zhiyong</a>, as well as numerous others who identified with the <a href="/wiki/New_Citizens%27_Movement" title="New Citizens&#39; Movement">New Citizens' Movement</a>. Prominent legal activist <a href="/wiki/Pu_Zhiqiang" title="Pu Zhiqiang">Pu Zhiqiang</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Weiquan_movement" title="Weiquan movement">Weiquan movement</a> was also arrested and detained.<sup id="cite_ref-350" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-350"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>347<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In 2017, the local government of the <a href="/wiki/Jiangxi" title="Jiangxi">Jiangxi province</a> told <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_China" title="Christianity in China">Christians</a> to replace their pictures of <a href="/wiki/Jesus" title="Jesus">Jesus</a> with Xi Jinping as part of a general campaign on unofficial churches in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-scmpJesus_351-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-scmpJesus-351"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>348<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>349<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-353" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-353"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>350<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> According to local social media, officials "transformed them from believing in religion to believing in the party."<sup id="cite_ref-scmpJesus_351-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-scmpJesus-351"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>348<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> According to activists, "Xi is waging the most severe systematic <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_China#Restrictions_and_international_interest" title="Christianity in China">suppression of Christianity</a> in the country since religious freedom was written into the Chinese constitution in 1982," and according to pastors and a group that monitors religion in China, has involved "destroying crosses, burning bibles, shutting churches and ordering followers to sign papers renouncing their faith."<sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>351<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Under Xi, the CCP has embraced assimilationist policies towards ethnic minorities, scaling back <a href="/wiki/Affirmative_action_in_China" title="Affirmative action in China">affirmative action</a> in the country by 2019,<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>352<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and scrapping a wording in October 2021 that guaranteed the rights of minority children to be educated in their native language, replacing it with one that emphasized teaching the national language.<sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>353<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2020, <a href="/wiki/Chen_Xiaojiang" title="Chen Xiaojiang">Chen Xiaojiang</a> was appointed as head of the <a href="/wiki/National_Ethnic_Affairs_Commission" title="National Ethnic Affairs Commission">National Ethnic Affairs Commission</a>, the first Han Chinese head of the body since 1954.<sup id="cite_ref-357" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-357"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>354<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> On 24 June 2022, <a href="/wiki/Pan_Yue_(politician)" title="Pan Yue (politician)">Pan Yue</a>, another Han Chinese, became the head of the commission, with him reportedly holding assimilationist policies toward ethnic minorities.<sup id="cite_ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>355<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi outlined his official views relations between the majority Han Chinese and ethnic minorities by saying "[n]either <a href="/wiki/Han_chauvinism" title="Han chauvinism">Han chauvinism</a> nor <a href="/wiki/Local_ethnic_chauvinism" class="mw-redirect" title="Local ethnic chauvinism">local ethnic chauvinism</a> is conducive to the development of a community for the Chinese nation."<sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>356<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Xinjiang">Xinjiang</h4></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Uyghurs_in_China" title="Persecution of Uyghurs in China">Persecution of Uyghurs in China</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Xi_Jinping_Entrance_Hall_at_the_XUAR_Museum.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Xi_Jinping_Entrance_Hall_at_the_XUAR_Museum.jpg/250px-Xi_Jinping_Entrance_Hall_at_the_XUAR_Museum.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="188" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Xi_Jinping_Entrance_Hall_at_the_XUAR_Museum.jpg/500px-Xi_Jinping_Entrance_Hall_at_the_XUAR_Museum.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="4608" data-file-height="3456" /></a><figcaption>Xi Jinping's picture at the entrance hall of the <a href="/wiki/Xinjiang_Museum" title="Xinjiang Museum">Xinjiang Museum</a> in <a href="/wiki/%C3%9Cr%C3%BCmqi" title="Ürümqi">Ürümqi</a>, August 2018</figcaption></figure>
<p>Following several terrorist attacks in <a href="/wiki/Xinjiang" title="Xinjiang">Xinjiang</a> in 2013 and 2014, the CCP leaders held a secret meeting to find a solution to the attacks,<sup id="cite_ref-:5_360-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:5-360"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>357<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> leading to Xi to launch the <a href="/wiki/Strike_Hard_Campaign_Against_Violent_Terrorism" title="Strike Hard Campaign Against Violent Terrorism">Strike Hard Campaign Against Violent Terrorism</a> in 2014, which involved mass detention, and surveillance of ethnic <a href="/wiki/Uyghurs" title="Uyghurs">Uyghurs</a> there.<sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>358<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ramzy-2019_362-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ramzy-2019-362"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>359<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The campaign included the detainment of 1.8 million people in <a href="/wiki/Xinjiang_internment_camps" title="Xinjiang internment camps">internment camps</a>, mostly Uyghurs but also including other ethnic and religious minorities, by 2020,<sup id="cite_ref-:5_360-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:5-360"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>357<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and a birth suppression campaign that led to a large drop in the Uyghur birth rate by 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-363" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-363"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>360<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Human rights groups and former inmates have described the camps as "concentration camps," where Uyghurs and other minorities have been forcibly assimilated into China's majority <a href="/wiki/Han_Chinese" title="Han Chinese">ethnic Han</a> society.<sup id="cite_ref-364" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-364"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>361<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> This program has been called a genocide by western observers, while <a href="/wiki/UN_Human_Rights_Office_report_on_Xinjiang" title="UN Human Rights Office report on Xinjiang">a report</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Office_of_the_United_Nations_High_Commissioner_for_Human_Rights" title="Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights">UN Human Rights Office</a> said they may amount to crimes against humanity.<sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>362<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-366" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-366"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>363<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Xinjiang_papers" title="Xinjiang papers">Internal Chinese government documents</a> leaked to the press in November 2019 showed that Xi personally ordered a security crackdown in Xinjiang, saying that the party must show "absolutely no mercy" and that officials use all the "weapons of the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_democratic_dictatorship" title="People&#39;s democratic dictatorship">people's democratic dictatorship</a>" to suppress those "infected with the virus of extremism."<sup id="cite_ref-Ramzy-2019_362-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ramzy-2019-362"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>359<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>364<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The papers also showed that Xi repeatedly discussed about <a href="/wiki/Islamic_extremism" title="Islamic extremism">Islamic extremism</a> in his speeches, likening it to a "virus" or a "drug" that could be only addressed by "a period of painful, interventionary treatment."<sup id="cite_ref-Ramzy-2019_362-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ramzy-2019-362"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>359<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> However, he also warned against the discrimination against Uyghurs and rejected proposals to eradicate <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_China" title="Islam in China">Islam in China</a>, calling that kind of viewpoint "biased, even wrong."<sup id="cite_ref-Ramzy-2019_362-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ramzy-2019-362"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>359<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi's exact role in the building of internment camps has not been publicly reported, though he's widely believed to be behind them and his words have been the source for major justifications in the crackdown in Xinjiang.<sup id="cite_ref-Economist-2022a_368-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Economist-2022a-368"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>365<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-369" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-369"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>366<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>During a four-day visit to Xinjiang in July 2022, Xi urged local officials to always listen to the people's voices<sup id="cite_ref-370" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-370"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>367<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and to do more in preservation of ethnic minority culture.<sup id="cite_ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>368<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He also inspected the <a href="/wiki/Xinjiang_Production_and_Construction_Corps" title="Xinjiang Production and Construction Corps">Xinjiang Production and Construction Corps</a> and praised its "great progress" in reform and development.<sup id="cite_ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>369<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> During another visit to Xinjiang in August 2023, Xi said in a speech that the region was "no longer a remote area" and should open up more for <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Xinjiang" class="mw-redirect" title="Tourism in Xinjiang">tourism</a> to attract domestic and foreign visitors.<sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>370<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>371<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="COVID-19_pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Chinese_government_response_to_COVID-19" title="Chinese government response to COVID-19">Chinese government response to COVID-19</a> and <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_mainland_China" title="COVID-19 pandemic in mainland China">COVID-19 pandemic in mainland China</a></div><p>On 20 January 2020, Xi commented for the first time on the emerging <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic" title="COVID-19 pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a> in Wuhan, and ordered "efforts to curb the spread" of the virus.<sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>372<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He gave premier Li Keqiang some responsibility over the COVID-19 response, in what has been suggested by <i>The Wall Street Journal</i> was an attempt to potentially insulate himself from criticism if the response failed.<sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>373<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The government initially responded to the pandemic with a lockdown and censorship, with the initial response causing widespread backlash within China.<sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>374<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He met with <a href="/wiki/Tedros_Adhanom_Ghebreyesus" title="Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus">Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus</a>, the director-general of the World Health Organization (WHO), on 28 January.<sup id="cite_ref-Steger-2020_378-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Steger-2020-378"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>375<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Der_Spiegel" title="Der Spiegel">Der Spiegel</a></i> reported that in January 2020 Xi pressured Tedros Adhanom to hold off on issuing a <a href="/wiki/Public_health_emergency_of_international_concern" title="Public health emergency of international concern">global warning</a> about the outbreak of COVID-19 and hold back information on human-to-human transmission of the virus, allegations denied by the WHO.<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>376<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> On 5 February, Xi met with Cambodian prime minister <a href="/wiki/Hun_Sen" title="Hun Sen">Hun Sen</a> in Beijing, the first foreign leader allowed into China since the outbreak.<sup id="cite_ref-Steger-2020_378-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Steger-2020-378"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>375<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> After the COVID-19 outbreak got under control in Wuhan, Xi visited the city on 10 March.<sup id="cite_ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>377<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><figure class="mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Sergio_Mattarella_and_Xi_Jinping_2019.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Sergio_Mattarella_and_Xi_Jinping_2019.jpg/250px-Sergio_Mattarella_and_Xi_Jinping_2019.jpg" decoding="async" width="225" height="150" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Sergio_Mattarella_and_Xi_Jinping_2019.jpg/500px-Sergio_Mattarella_and_Xi_Jinping_2019.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="3543" data-file-height="2362" /></a><figcaption>Italian president <a href="/wiki/Sergio_Mattarella" title="Sergio Mattarella">Sergio Mattarella</a> with Xi in March 2019</figcaption></figure>
<p>After getting the outbreak in Wuhan under control, Xi has favoured what has officially been termed "dynamic <a href="/wiki/Zero-COVID" title="Zero-COVID">zero-COVID policy</a>"<sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>378<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> that aims to control and suppress the virus as much as possible within the country's borders. This has involved local lockdowns and mass-testing.<sup id="cite_ref-Wong-2022_382-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wong-2022-382"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>379<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> While initially credited for China's suppression of the COVID-19 outbreak, the policy was later criticized by foreign and some domestic observers for being out of touch with the rest of the world and taking a heavy toll on the economy.<sup id="cite_ref-Wong-2022_382-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wong-2022-382"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>379<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> This approach has especially come under criticism during a 2022 lockdown on Shanghai, which forced millions to their homes and damaged the city's economy,<sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>380<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> denting the image of <a href="/wiki/Li_Qiang" title="Li Qiang">Li Qiang</a>, close Xi ally and Party secretary of the city.<sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>381<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Conversely, Xi has said that the policy was designed to protect people's life safety.<sup id="cite_ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>382<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> On 23 July 2022, the <a href="/wiki/National_Health_Commission" title="National Health Commission">National Health Commission</a> reported that Xi and other top leaders have taken the local COVID-19 vaccines.<sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>383<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>At the 20th CCP Congress, Xi confirmed the continuation of the zero-COVID policy,<sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>384<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> stating he would "unswervingly" carry out "dynamic zero-COVID" and promising to "resolutely win the battle,"<sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>385<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> though China started a limited easing of the policies in the following weeks.<sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>386<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In November 2022, <a href="/wiki/2022_COVID-19_protests_in_China" title="2022 COVID-19 protests in China">protests</a> broke out against China's COVID-19 policies, with a <a href="/wiki/2022_%C3%9Cr%C3%BCmqi_fire" title="2022 Ürümqi fire">fire in a high-rise apartment building in Ürümqi</a> being the trigger.<sup id="cite_ref-Che-2022_390-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Che-2022-390"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>387<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The protests were held in multiple major cities, with some of the protesters demanding the end of Xi's and the CCP's rule.<sup id="cite_ref-Che-2022_390-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Che-2022-390"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>387<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The protests were mostly suppressed by December,<sup id="cite_ref-Che-2022_390-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Che-2022-390"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>387<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> though the government further eased COVID-19 restrictions in the time since.<sup id="cite_ref-391" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-391"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>388<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> On 7 December 2022, China announced large-scale changes to its COVID-19 policy, including allowing quarantine at home for mild infections, reducing of <a href="/wiki/Polymerase_chain_reaction" title="Polymerase chain reaction">PCR testing</a>, and decreasing the power of local officials to implement lockdowns.<sup id="cite_ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>389<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Environmental_policy">Environmental policy</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping_Thought_on_Ecological_Civilization" title="Xi Jinping Thought on Ecological Civilization">Xi Jinping Thought on Ecological Civilization</a> and <a href="/wiki/Environmental_policy_in_China" title="Environmental policy in China">Environmental policy in China</a></div>
<p>Xi identifies environmental protection as one of China's five major priorities for national progress.<sup id="cite_ref-:03_393-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:03-393"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>390<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 164">&#58;&#8202;164&#8202;</span></sup> Xi has popularized a metaphor of "two mountains" to emphasize the importance of environmental protection.<sup id="cite_ref-:03_393-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:03-393"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>390<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 164">&#58;&#8202;164&#8202;</span></sup> The concept is that a mountain made of gold or silver is valuable, but <a href="/wiki/Clear_waters_and_green_mountains" title="Clear waters and green mountains">green mountains with clear waters are more valuable</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-:03_393-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:03-393"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>390<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 164">&#58;&#8202;164&#8202;</span></sup> The slogan's meaning is that economic development priorities must also provide for economic protection.<sup id="cite_ref-:03_393-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:03-393"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>390<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 164">&#58;&#8202;164&#8202;</span></sup>
</p><p>In September 2020, Xi announced that China will "strengthen its 2030 climate target (NDC), peak emissions before 2030 and aim to achieve <a href="/wiki/Carbon_neutrality" class="mw-redirect" title="Carbon neutrality">carbon neutrality</a> before 2060."<sup id="cite_ref-CAT-2020_394-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CAT-2020-394"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>391<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> If accomplished, this would lower the expected rise in global temperature by 0.2–0.3&#160;°C – "the biggest single reduction ever estimated by the Climate Action Tracker."<sup id="cite_ref-CAT-2020_394-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CAT-2020-394"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>391<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi mentioned the link between the COVID-19 pandemic and nature destruction as one of the reasons for the decision, saying that "Humankind can no longer afford to ignore the repeated warnings of nature."<sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>392<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> On 27 September, Chinese scientists presented a detailed plan how to achieve the target.<sup id="cite_ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>393<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In September 2021, Xi announced that China will not build "coal-fired power projects abroad, which was said to be potentially "pivotal" in reducing emissions. The Belt and Road Initiative did not include financing such projects already in the first half of 2021.<sup id="cite_ref-397" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-397"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>394<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Xi Jinping did not attend <a href="/wiki/2021_United_Nations_Climate_Change_Conference" title="2021 United Nations Climate Change Conference">COP26</a> personally. However, a Chinese delegation led by climate change envoy <a href="/wiki/Xie_Zhenhua_(politician)" title="Xie Zhenhua (politician)">Xie Zhenhua</a> did attend.<sup id="cite_ref-398" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-398"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>395<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-399" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-399"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>396<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> During the conference, the United States and China agreed on a framework to reduce <a href="/wiki/GHG_emission" class="mw-redirect" title="GHG emission">GHG emission</a> by co-operating on different measures.<sup id="cite_ref-400" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-400"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>397<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Governance_style">Governance style</h3></div>
<p>Known as a very secretive leader, little is known publicly about how Xi makes political decisions, or how he came to power.<sup id="cite_ref-Economist-2022b_401-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Economist-2022b-401"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>398<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Myers-2018_402-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Myers-2018-402"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>399<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi's speeches generally get released months or years after they are made.<sup id="cite_ref-Economist-2022b_401-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Economist-2022b-401"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>398<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi has also never given a press conference since becoming paramount leader, except in rare joint press conferences with foreign leaders.<sup id="cite_ref-Economist-2022b_401-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Economist-2022b-401"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>398<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-403" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-403"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>400<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <i>The Wall Street Journal</i> reported that Xi prefers micromanaging in governance, in contrast to previous leaders such as Hu Jintao who left details of major policies to lower-ranking officials.<sup id="cite_ref-Chin-2021_127-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chin-2021-127"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>124<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Reportedly, ministerial officials try to get Xi's attention in various ways, with some creating slide shows and audio reports. <i>The Wall Street Journal</i> also reported that Xi created a performance-review system in 2018 to give evaluations on officials on various measures, including loyalty.<sup id="cite_ref-Chin-2021_127-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chin-2021-127"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>124<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> According to <i>The Economist</i>, Xi's orders have generally been vague, leaving lower level officials to interpret his words.<sup id="cite_ref-Economist-2022a_368-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Economist-2022a-368"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>365<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Chinese state media Xinhua News Agency said that Xi "personally reviews every draft of major policy documents" and "all reports submitted to him, no matter how late in the evening, were returned with instructions the following morning."<sup id="cite_ref-Blachard-2017_404-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Blachard-2017-404"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>401<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> With regard to behavior of Communist Party members, Xi emphasizes the "Two Musts" (members must not be arrogant or rash and must keep their hard-working spirit) and the "Six Nos" (members must say no to formalism, bureaucracy, gift-giving, luxurious birthday celebrations, hedonism, and extravagance).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMarquisQiao202252_405-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMarquisQiao202252-405"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>402<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi called for officials to practice <a href="/wiki/Self-criticism_(Marxism%E2%80%93Leninism)" class="mw-redirect" title="Self-criticism (Marxism–Leninism)">self-criticism</a> which, according to observers, is in order to appear less corrupt and more popular among the people.<sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>403<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>404<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-408" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-408"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>405<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> According to Japanese diplomat <a href="/wiki/Hideo_Tarumi" title="Hideo Tarumi">Hideo Tarumi</a>, who served as the Japanese ambassador to China, Xi has engaged in heavy process of centralization in order to maintain the legitimacy of the rule of Chinese Communist Party.<sup id="cite_ref-409" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-409"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>406<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Political_positions">Political positions</h2></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Ideology_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Ideology of the Chinese Communist Party">Ideology of the Chinese Communist Party</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1224211176" /><div class="quotebox pullquote floatright" style="width:25em; ;">
<blockquote class="quotebox-quote left-aligned" style=""><p>
A party and its authority rests on winning the hearts and minds of the people. What the public opposes and hates, we must address and resolve.</p><div class="paragraphbreak" style="margin-top:0.5em"></div><p> [M]aterial and cultural needs grown; demands for democracy, rule of law, fairness and justice, security, and a better environment are also increasing each day.
</p></blockquote>
<div style="padding-bottom: 0; padding-top: 0.5em"><cite class="left-aligned" style="">— Xi Jinping during a speech in 2017<sup id="cite_ref-voa2017oct_410-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-voa2017oct-410"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>407<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></cite></div>
</div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Chinese_Dream">Chinese Dream</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Dream" title="Chinese Dream">Chinese Dream</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Lujiazui_2016.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Lujiazui_2016.jpg/250px-Lujiazui_2016.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Lujiazui_2016.jpg/500px-Lujiazui_2016.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1800" data-file-height="1200" /></a><figcaption>According to <i><a href="/wiki/Qiushi" title="Qiushi">Qiushi</a></i>, the Chinese Dream is about Chinese prosperity, collective effort, socialism, and national glory.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Xi and CCP ideologues coined the phrase "Chinese Dream" to describe his overarching plans for China as its leader. Xi first used the phrase during a high-profile visit to the <a href="/wiki/National_Museum_of_China" title="National Museum of China">National Museum of China</a> on 29 November 2012, where he and his <a href="/wiki/Politburo_Standing_Committee_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Politburo Standing Committee of the Chinese Communist Party">Standing Committee</a> colleagues were attending a "national revival" exhibition. Since then, the phrase has become the signature political slogan of the Xi era.<sup id="cite_ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>408<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>409<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The origin of the term "Chinese Dream" is unclear. While the phrase has been used before by journalists and scholars,<sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>410<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> some publications have posited the term likely drew its inspiration from the concept of the <a href="/wiki/American_Dream" title="American Dream">American Dream</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-414" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-414"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>411<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <i>The Economist</i> noted the abstract and seemingly accessible nature of the concept with no specific overarching policy stipulations may be a deliberate departure from the jargon-heavy ideologies of his predecessors.<sup id="cite_ref-415" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-415"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>412<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi has linked the "Chinese Dream" with the phrase "<a href="/wiki/Great_rejuvenation_of_the_Chinese_nation" title="Great rejuvenation of the Chinese nation">great rejuvenation of the Chinese nation</a>."<sup id="cite_ref-416" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-416"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>413<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Culture">Culture</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping_Thought_on_Culture" title="Xi Jinping Thought on Culture">Xi Jinping Thought on Culture</a></div>
<p>In recent years, top political leaders of the CCP such as Xi have overseen the rehabilitation of ancient Chinese philosophical figures like <a href="/wiki/Han_Fei" title="Han Fei">Han Fei</a> into the mainstream of Chinese thought alongside <a href="/wiki/Confucianism" title="Confucianism">Confucianism</a>. At a meeting with other officials in 2013, he quoted <a href="/wiki/Confucius" title="Confucius">Confucius</a>, saying "he who rules by virtue is like the Pole Star, it maintains its place, and the multitude of stars pay homage." While visiting <a href="/wiki/Shandong" title="Shandong">Shandong</a>, the birthplace of Confucius, in November, he told scholars that the Western world was "suffering a crisis of confidence" and that the CCP has been "the loyal inheritor and promoter of China's outstanding <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_culture" class="mw-redirect" title="Traditional Chinese culture">traditional culture</a>."<sup id="cite_ref-417" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-417"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>414<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>According to several analysts, Xi's leadership has been characterised by a resurgence of the ancient political philosophy <a href="/wiki/Legalism_(Chinese_philosophy)" title="Legalism (Chinese philosophy)">Legalism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-418" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-418"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>415<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-419" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-419"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>416<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-tdma_420-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tdma-420"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>417<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Han Fei gained new prominence with favourable citations; one sentence of Han Fei's that Xi quoted appeared thousands of times in official Chinese media at the local, provincial, and national levels.<sup id="cite_ref-tdma_420-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tdma-420"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>417<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi has additionally supported the <a href="/wiki/Neo-Confucianism" title="Neo-Confucianism">Neo-Confucian</a> philosopher <a href="/wiki/Wang_Yangming" title="Wang Yangming">Wang Yangming</a>, telling local leaders to promote him.<sup id="cite_ref-421" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-421"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>418<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
