</p><p>Since the <a href="/wiki/18th_National_Congress_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="18th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party">18th</a> <a href="/wiki/18th_National_Congress_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="18th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party">Party Congress</a>, Xi  has emphasized utilizing red resources, telling red stories, and inheriting red genes.<sup id="cite_ref-422" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-422"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>419<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: xii">&#58;&#8202;xii&#8202;</span></sup>
</p><p>On 15 October 2014, Xi Jinping emulated the <a href="/wiki/Yan%27an_Forum" title="Yan&#39;an Forum">Yan'an Forum</a> with his 'Speech at the Forum on Literature and Art.'<sup id="cite_ref-:13_423-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:13-423"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>420<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 15">&#58;&#8202;15&#8202;</span></sup> Consistent with Mao's view in the Yan'an Talks, Xi believes works of art should be judged by political criteria.<sup id="cite_ref-:13_423-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:13-423"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>420<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 16">&#58;&#8202;16&#8202;</span></sup> In 2021, Xi quoted the Yan'an Talks during the opening ceremony of the 11th National Congress of the <a href="/wiki/China_Federation_of_Literary_and_Art_Circles" title="China Federation of Literary and Art Circles">China Federation of Literary and Art Circles</a> and the 10th National Congress of the <a href="/wiki/China_Writers_Association" title="China Writers Association">Chinese Writers Association</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMarquisQiao2022174_424-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMarquisQiao2022174-424"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>421<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> According to Xi, art should be judged by political criteria.<sup id="cite_ref-:13_423-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:13-423"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>420<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 16">&#58;&#8202;16&#8202;</span></sup> This view rejects the concept of <a href="/wiki/Art_for_art%27s_sake" title="Art for art&#39;s sake">art-for-art's-sake</a> and contends that art should serve the goal of national rejuvenation.<sup id="cite_ref-:13_423-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:13-423"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>420<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 16">&#58;&#8202;16&#8202;</span></sup> Xi criticizes market-driven art which he deems sensationalist, particularly works which "exaggerate society's dark side" for profit.<sup id="cite_ref-:13_423-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:13-423"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>420<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 16">&#58;&#8202;16&#8202;</span></sup> He ordered the arts industry to "tell China's stories and spread Chinese voices to strengthen the country's international communication capacity."<sup id="cite_ref-425" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-425"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>422<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi states that Chinese writers should follow the Party's leadership, serve the cause of socialism, and "let people see the good, feel hope, [and] have dreams".<sup id="cite_ref-:023_426-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:023-426"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>423<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 252">&#58;&#8202;252&#8202;</span></sup>
</p><p>Xi has also overseen a revival of traditional Chinese culture, breaking from the CCP's previous path, which had often attacked it.<sup id="cite_ref-427" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-427"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>424<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He has called traditional culture the "soul" of the nation and the "foundation" of the CCP's culture.<sup id="cite_ref-428" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-428"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>425<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi has also called for integrating the basic tenets of Marxism with China's traditional culture.<sup id="cite_ref-:12_284-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:12-284"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>281<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Hanfu" title="Hanfu">Hanfu</a>, the traditional dress of Han Chinese, has seen a revival under him, associated with the revival of traditional culture.<sup id="cite_ref-429" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-429"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>426<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He has established the "<a href="/wiki/Four_Confidences" title="Four Confidences">four matters of confidence</a>," which has later been added to the CCP constitution, calling for CCP members, government officials and the Chinese people to be "confident in our chosen path, confident in our guiding theories, confident in our political system, and confident in our culture." He has unveiled Global Civilisation initiative in 2023, calling for "respecting the diversity of civilisations, advocating the common values of humanity, valuing the inheritance and innovation of civilisations, and strengthening international people-to-people exchanges and cooperation".<sup id="cite_ref-:12_284-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:12-284"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>281<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi supports a socialist artistic revival, including the promotion of patriotic art and red classics.<sup id="cite_ref-:023_426-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:023-426"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>423<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page: 253">&#58;&#8202;253&#8202;</span></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Ideology">Ideology</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Eight-point_Regulation" title="Eight-point Regulation">Eight-point Regulation</a></div>
<p>Xi has said that "only socialism can save China."<sup id="cite_ref-430" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-430"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>427<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi has also declared <a href="/wiki/Socialism_with_Chinese_characteristics" title="Socialism with Chinese characteristics">socialism with Chinese characteristics</a> to be the "only correct path to realize national rejuvenation."<sup id="cite_ref-431" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-431"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>428<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/BBC_News" title="BBC News">BBC News</a>, while the CCP was perceived to have abandoned its communist ideology since it initiated <a href="/wiki/Reform_and_opening_up" title="Reform and opening up">economic reforms</a> in the 1970s, Xi is believed by some observers to be more believing in the "idea of a communist project,"<sup id="cite_ref-432" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-432"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>429<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> being described as a <a href="/wiki/Marxist%E2%80%93Leninist" class="mw-redirect" title="Marxist–Leninist">Marxist–Leninist</a> by former Australian prime minister Kevin Rudd.<sup id="cite_ref-433" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-433"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>430<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi's emphasis on prioritizing ideology has included re-asserting the Party's goal of eventually <a href="/wiki/Socialist_mode_of_production" title="Socialist mode of production">realizing communism</a> and reprimanding those who dismiss communism as impractical or irrelevant.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPiekeHofman202248_183-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPiekeHofman202248-183"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>180<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi described the communist ideal as the "calcium" in a Party member's spine, without which the Party member would suffer the "osteoporosis" of political decay and be unable to stand upright.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPiekeHofman202248_183-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPiekeHofman202248-183"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>180<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Subscribing to the view that socialism will eventually triumph over capitalism, Xi has said "Marx and Engels's <a href="/wiki/Dialectical_materialism" title="Dialectical materialism">analysis of the basic contradictions</a> of <a href="/wiki/Capitalist_mode_of_production_(Marxist_theory)" title="Capitalist mode of production (Marxist theory)">capitalist society</a> is not outdated, nor is the <a href="/wiki/Historical_materialism" title="Historical materialism">historical materialist view</a> that capitalism is bound to die out and socialism bound to win."<sup id="cite_ref-Hancock-2022_434-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hancock-2022-434"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>431<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi has overseen the increase of "Socialist Political Economy With Chinese Characteristics" as a major study topic for academics in China, aiming to decrease the influence of Western-influenced economics.<sup id="cite_ref-Hancock-2022_434-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hancock-2022-434"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>431<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Though he has called a stop to what he considers to be "disorderly expansion of capital," he has also said that "it is necessary to stimulate the vitality of capital of all types, including nonpublic capital, and give full play to its positive role."<sup id="cite_ref-Hancock-2022_434-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hancock-2022-434"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>431<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1224211176" /><div class="quotebox pullquote floatright" style="width:25em; ;">
<blockquote class="quotebox-quote left-aligned" style="">
<p>China's success proves that socialism is not dead. It is thriving. Just imagine this: had socialism failed in China, had our communist party collapsed like the party in the Soviet Union, then global socialism would lapse into a long dark age. And communism, like Karl Marx once said, would be a haunting spectre lingering in limbo.
</p>
</blockquote>
<div style="padding-bottom: 0; padding-top: 0.5em"><cite class="left-aligned" style="">— Xi Jinping during a speech in 2018<sup id="cite_ref-:12bb_435-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:12bb-435"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>432<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></cite></div>
</div>
<p>Xi has supported greater CCP control over the PRC, saying "government, the military, society and schools, north, south, east and west – <a href="/wiki/The_Party_leads_everything" title="The Party leads everything">the party leads them all</a>."<sup id="cite_ref-436" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-436"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>433<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/100th_Anniversary_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="100th Anniversary of the Chinese Communist Party">100th anniversary of the CCP</a> in 2021, he said that "without the Communist Party of China, there would be no new China and no national rejuvenation," and that "the leadership of the Party is the defining feature of socialism with Chinese characteristics and constitutes the greatest strength of this system."<sup id="cite_ref-437" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-437"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>434<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He has said that China, despite many setbacks, has achieved great progress under the CCP, saying that "socialism with Chinese characteristics has become the standard-bearer of 21st-century socialist development."<sup id="cite_ref-:12bb_435-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:12bb-435"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>432<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> However, he has also warned that it will take a long time for China under the CCP to complete its rejuvenation, and during this timeframe, party members must be vigilant to not let CCP rule collapse.<sup id="cite_ref-:12bb_435-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:12bb-435"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>432<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi has spoken out against "<a href="/wiki/Historical_nihilism" title="Historical nihilism">historical nihilism</a>," meaning historical viewpoints that challenge the official line of the CCP.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWong2023181_438-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWong2023181-438"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>435<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi said that one of the reasons for the <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Dissolution of the Soviet Union">collapse of the Soviet Union</a> has been historical nihilism.<sup id="cite_ref-439" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-439"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>436<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Xi has ruled out a <a href="/wiki/Multi-party_system" title="Multi-party system">multi-party system</a> for China, saying that "constitutional monarchy, imperial restoration, parliamentarism, a multi-party system and a presidential system, we considered them, tried them, but none worked."<sup id="cite_ref-440" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-440"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>437<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> However, Xi considers China to be a <a href="/wiki/Democracy_in_China" title="Democracy in China">democracy</a>, saying that "China's <a href="/wiki/Socialist_democracy" title="Socialist democracy">socialist democracy</a> is the most comprehensive, genuine and effective democracy."<sup id="cite_ref-Drinhausen-2009_441-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Drinhausen-2009-441"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>438<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> China's definition of democracy is different from <a href="/wiki/Liberal_democracies" class="mw-redirect" title="Liberal democracies">liberal democracies</a> and is rooted in Marxism–Leninism, and is based on the phrases people's democratic dictatorship and <a href="/wiki/Democratic_centralism" title="Democratic centralism">democratic centralism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Drinhausen-2009_441-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Drinhausen-2009-441"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>438<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi has additionally coined the term whole-process people's democracy which he said was about having "the people as masters."<sup id="cite_ref-442" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-442"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>439<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Foreign analysts and observers have widely disputed that China is a democracy, saying that it is a one-party authoritarian state and Xi an authoritarian leader.<sup id="cite_ref-dictatorandauthoritarian_449-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dictatorandauthoritarian-449"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>446<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi has additionally rejected <a href="/wiki/Westernization" title="Westernization">Westernisation</a> as the only way to modernize, instead promoting what he says is "<a href="/wiki/Chinese-style_modernization" title="Chinese-style modernization">Chinese-style modernisation</a>."<sup id="cite_ref-450" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-450"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>447<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He has identified five concepts as part of Chinese-style modernisation, including modernisation of a huge population, common prosperity, material and cultural-ethical advancement, harmony between humanity and nature, and peaceful development.<sup id="cite_ref-451" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-451"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>448<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Xi_Jinping_Thought">Xi Jinping Thought</h4></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping_Thought" title="Xi Jinping Thought">Xi Jinping Thought</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:A_political_slogan_on_the_wall_in_Longhua_District,_Shenzhen,_Guangdong,_China,_picture1.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/A_political_slogan_on_the_wall_in_Longhua_District%2C_Shenzhen%2C_Guangdong%2C_China%2C_picture1.jpg/250px-A_political_slogan_on_the_wall_in_Longhua_District%2C_Shenzhen%2C_Guangdong%2C_China%2C_picture1.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="188" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/A_political_slogan_on_the_wall_in_Longhua_District%2C_Shenzhen%2C_Guangdong%2C_China%2C_picture1.jpg/500px-A_political_slogan_on_the_wall_in_Longhua_District%2C_Shenzhen%2C_Guangdong%2C_China%2C_picture1.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="3968" data-file-height="2976" /></a><figcaption>A billboard promoting <a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping_Thought" title="Xi Jinping Thought">Xi Jinping Thought</a> in <a href="/wiki/Shenzhen" title="Shenzhen">Shenzhen</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>In September 2017, the CCP Central Committee decided that Xi's political philosophies, generally referred to as "Xi Jinping Thought on Socialism with Chinese Characteristics for a New Era," would become part of the Party Constitution.<sup id="cite_ref-452" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-452"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>449<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-453" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-453"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>450<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi first made mention of the "Thought on Socialism with Chinese Characteristics for a New Era" in his opening day speech delivered to the 19th Party Congress in October 2017. His Politburo Standing Committee colleagues, in their own reviews of Xi's keynote address at the Congress, prepended the name "Xi Jinping" in front of "Thought."<sup id="cite_ref-xithought2_454-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-xithought2-454"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>451<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> On 24 October 2017, at its closing session, the 19th Party Congress approved the incorporation of Xi Jinping Thought into the Constitution of the CCP,<sup id="cite_ref-PhillipsGuardian2_142-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PhillipsGuardian2-142"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>139<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> while in March 2018, the National People's Congress changed the state constitution to include Xi Jinping Thought.<sup id="cite_ref-455" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-455"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>452<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:201901_Xi_Jinping%27s_books_at_Shanghai_Library.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/201901_Xi_Jinping%27s_books_at_Shanghai_Library.jpg/250px-201901_Xi_Jinping%27s_books_at_Shanghai_Library.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="188" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/201901_Xi_Jinping%27s_books_at_Shanghai_Library.jpg/500px-201901_Xi_Jinping%27s_books_at_Shanghai_Library.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="4032" data-file-height="3024" /></a><figcaption><i><a href="/wiki/The_Governance_of_China" title="The Governance of China">The Governance of China</a></i> in different languages presented at <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Library" title="Shanghai Library">Shanghai Library</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>Xi himself has described the Thought as part of the broad framework created around socialism with Chinese characteristics, a term coined by Deng Xiaoping that places China in the <a href="/wiki/Primary_stage_of_socialism" title="Primary stage of socialism">primary stage of socialism</a>. In official party documentation and pronouncements by Xi's colleagues, the Thought is said to be a continuation of <a href="/wiki/Marxism%E2%80%93Leninism" title="Marxism–Leninism">Marxism–Leninism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mao_Zedong_Thought" class="mw-redirect" title="Mao Zedong Thought">Mao Zedong Thought</a>, <a href="/wiki/Deng_Xiaoping_Theory" title="Deng Xiaoping Theory">Deng Xiaoping Theory</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Three_Represents" title="Three Represents">Three Represents</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Scientific_Outlook_on_Development" title="Scientific Outlook on Development">Scientific Outlook on Development</a>, as part of a series of guiding ideologies that embody "Marxism adopted to Chinese conditions" and contemporary considerations.<sup id="cite_ref-xithought2_454-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-xithought2-454"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>451<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It has additionally been described as the "21st century Marxism" by two professors in the Central Party School of the CCP.<sup id="cite_ref-Page-2020_17-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Page-2020-17"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>16<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Wang_Huning" title="Wang Huning">Wang Huning</a>, a top political adviser and a close ally of Xi, has been described as pivotal to developing Xi Jinping Thought.<sup id="cite_ref-Page-2020_17-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Page-2020-17"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>16<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The concepts and context behind Xi Jinping Thought are elaborated in Xi's <i><a href="/wiki/The_Governance_of_China" title="The Governance of China">The Governance of China</a></i> book series, published by the <a href="/wiki/Foreign_Languages_Press" title="Foreign Languages Press">Foreign Languages Press</a> for an international audience. Volume one was published in September 2014, followed by volume two in November 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-456" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-456"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>453<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Xuexi_Qiangguo" title="Xuexi Qiangguo">Xuexi Qiangguo</a></i>, an app for teaching Xi Jinping Thought had become the most popular smartphone app in China in 2019, as the CCP launched a new campaign that calls on its cadres to immerse themselves in the political doctrine every day.<sup id="cite_ref-457" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-457"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>454<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Personal_life">Personal life</h2></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Family">Family</h3></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Peng_Liyuan,_Xi_Jinping_and_Barack_Obama_in_the_Lincoln_Bedroom.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Peng_Liyuan%2C_Xi_Jinping_and_Barack_Obama_in_the_Lincoln_Bedroom.jpg/250px-Peng_Liyuan%2C_Xi_Jinping_and_Barack_Obama_in_the_Lincoln_Bedroom.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Peng_Liyuan%2C_Xi_Jinping_and_Barack_Obama_in_the_Lincoln_Bedroom.jpg/500px-Peng_Liyuan%2C_Xi_Jinping_and_Barack_Obama_in_the_Lincoln_Bedroom.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1500" data-file-height="1000" /></a><figcaption>Xi Jinping, <a href="/wiki/Peng_Liyuan" title="Peng Liyuan">Peng Liyuan</a> and U.S. president <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> in the Lincoln Bedroom</figcaption></figure>
<p>Xi's first marriage was to <a href="/wiki/Ke_Lingling" title="Ke Lingling">Ke Lingling</a>, the daughter of <a href="/wiki/Ke_Hua" title="Ke Hua">Ke Hua</a>, China's ambassador to the United Kingdom in the early 1980s. They divorced within a few years.<sup id="cite_ref-458" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-458"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>455<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The two were said to fight "almost every day," and after the divorce, Ke moved to England.<sup id="cite_ref-newyorker2_8-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-newyorker2-8"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>7<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 1987, Xi married the prominent Chinese folk singer Peng Liyuan.<sup id="cite_ref-459" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-459"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>456<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi and Peng were introduced by friends as many Chinese couples were in the 1980s. Xi was reputedly academic during their courtship, inquiring about singing techniques.<sup id="cite_ref-460" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-460"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>457<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Peng Liyuan, a <a href="/wiki/Celebrity" title="Celebrity">household name</a> in China, was better known to the public than Xi until his political elevation. The couple frequently lived apart due largely to their separate professional lives. Peng has played a much more visible role as China's "first lady" compared to her predecessors; for example, Peng hosted U.S. First Lady <a href="/wiki/Michelle_Obama" title="Michelle Obama">Michelle Obama</a> on her high-profile visit to China in March 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-461" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-461"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>458<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Xi and Peng have a daughter named <a href="/wiki/Xi_Mingze" title="Xi Mingze">Xi Mingze</a>, who graduated from <a href="/wiki/Harvard_University" title="Harvard University">Harvard University</a> in the spring of 2015. While at Harvard, she used a pseudonym and studied Psychology and English.<sup id="cite_ref-462" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-462"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>459<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi's family has a home in <a href="/wiki/Jade_Spring_Hill" title="Jade Spring Hill">Jade Spring Hill</a>, a garden and residential area in north-western Beijing run by the CMC.<sup id="cite_ref-463" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-463"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>460<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In June 2012, <a href="/wiki/Bloomberg_News" title="Bloomberg News">Bloomberg News</a> reported that members of Xi's extended family have substantial business interests, although there was no evidence he had intervened to assist them.<sup id="cite_ref-464" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-464"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>461<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The Bloomberg News website was blocked in <a href="/wiki/Mainland_China" title="Mainland China">mainland China</a> in response to the article.<sup id="cite_ref-465" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-465"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>462<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Since Xi embarked on an anti-corruption campaign, <i>The New York Times</i> reported members of his family were selling their corporate and real estate investments beginning in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-466" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-466"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>463<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Relatives of highly placed Chinese officials, including seven current and former senior leaders of the Politburo of the CCP, have been named in the <a href="/wiki/Panama_Papers" title="Panama Papers">Panama Papers</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Deng_Jiagui" title="Deng Jiagui">Deng Jiagui</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-467" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-467"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>464<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi's brother-in-law. Deng had two <a href="/wiki/Shell_corporation" title="Shell corporation">shell companies</a> in the <a href="/wiki/British_Virgin_Islands" title="British Virgin Islands">British Virgin Islands</a> while Xi was a member of the Politburo Standing Committee, which became dormant by the time Xi became general secretary of the CCP in November 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-468" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-468"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>465<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Personality">Personality</h3></div>
<p>Peng described Xi as hardworking and down-to-earth: "When he comes home, I've never felt as if there's some leader in the house. In my eyes, he's just my husband."<sup id="cite_ref-469" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-469"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>466<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 1992, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Washington_Post" title="The Washington Post">The Washington Post</a></i> journalist Lena H. Sun had an interview with Xi, then CCP secretary of Fuzhou; Sun described Xi as considerably more at ease and confident than many officials his age, and said that he talked without consulting notes.<sup id="cite_ref-470" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-470"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>467<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He was described in a 2011 <i>The Washington Post</i> article by those who know him as "pragmatic, serious, cautious, hard-working, down to earth and low-key." He was described as a good hand at problem solving and "seemingly uninterested in the trappings of high office."<sup id="cite_ref-471" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-471"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>468<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The Chinese state media has also cast him as a fatherly figure and a man of the people, determined to stand up for Chinese interests.<sup id="cite_ref-Myers-2018_402-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Myers-2018-402"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>399<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Soccer">Soccer</h3></div>
<p>Xi is an avid soccer fan.<sup id="cite_ref-soccer_472-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-soccer-472"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>469<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> While working in Hebei, it was reported that Xi often asked his friend <a href="/wiki/Nie_Weiping" title="Nie Weiping">Nie Weiping</a>, a professional <a href="/wiki/Go_(game)" title="Go (game)">Go</a> player, for soccer tickets.<sup id="cite_ref-473" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-473"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>470<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> During a visit to <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland" title="Republic of Ireland">Ireland</a> in 2012 as China's vice-president, Xi showcased his soccer technique at <a href="/wiki/Croke_Park" title="Croke Park">Croke Park</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-soccer_472-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-soccer-472"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>469<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2011, Xi outlined a vision to turn China from a footballing minnow to a soccer superpower. He outlined a three-stage plan for the national team: to qualify for another <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup" title="FIFA World Cup">World Cup</a>, to host a World Cup and to win a World Cup.<sup id="cite_ref-foot_474-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-foot-474"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>471<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2015, Xi approved China's 50-point plan for the sport, which included including soccer in the national school curriculum and setting up 50,000 soccer schools in the country by 2025.<sup id="cite_ref-475" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-475"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>472<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> However, according to <a href="/wiki/CNN" title="CNN">CNN</a>, poor financial decisions and alleged high-level corruption coupled with a <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_mainland_China" title="COVID-19 pandemic in mainland China">three-year pandemic</a> have left the sport in tatters.<sup id="cite_ref-foot_474-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-foot-474"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>471<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2023, Xi said he is "not so sure" of the abilities of the national team.<sup id="cite_ref-476" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-476"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>473<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Interests">Interests</h3></div>
<p>Unlike previous Chinese leaders, Chinese state media has given a more encompassing view of Xi's private life, although still strictly controlled. According to Xinhua News Agency, Xi would swim one kilometer and walk every day as long as there was time, and is interested in foreign writers, especially Russian.<sup id="cite_ref-Blachard-2017_404-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Blachard-2017-404"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>401<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Some of his favorite foreign authors include <a href="/wiki/Leo_Tolstoy" title="Leo Tolstoy">Leo Tolstoy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Sholokhov" title="Mikhail Sholokhov">Mikhail Sholokhov</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-477" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-477"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>474<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Victor_Hugo" title="Victor Hugo">Victor Hugo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Honor%C3%A9_de_Balzac" title="Honoré de Balzac">Honoré de Balzac</a>, <a href="/wiki/Johann_Wolfgang_von_Goethe" title="Johann Wolfgang von Goethe">Johann Wolfgang von Goethe</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jack_London" title="Jack London">Jack London</a>. Xi reportedly invoked <i><a href="/wiki/What_Is_to_Be_Done%3F_(novel)" title="What Is to Be Done? (novel)">What Is to Be Done?</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Nikolay_Chernyshevsky" title="Nikolay Chernyshevsky">Nikolay Chernyshevsky</a> as a guide during the <a href="/wiki/16th_BRICS_summit" title="16th BRICS summit">16th BRICS summit</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-478" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-478"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>475<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Xi is reported to also like films and TV shows such as <i><a href="/wiki/Saving_Private_Ryan" title="Saving Private Ryan">Saving Private Ryan</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-479" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-479"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>476<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Sleepless_in_Seattle" title="Sleepless in Seattle">Sleepless in Seattle</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Godfather" title="The Godfather">The Godfather</a></i><sup id="cite_ref-480" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-480"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>477<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <i><a href="/wiki/Game_of_Thrones" title="Game of Thrones">Game of Thrones</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-481" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-481"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>478<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and he has praised Chinese independent film-maker <a href="/wiki/Jia_Zhangke" title="Jia Zhangke">Jia Zhangke</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-482" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-482"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>479<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In a speech in 2014, Xi described himself as a "moderate <a href="/wiki/Tea" title="Tea">tea</a> drinker" and as a "passionate <a href="/wiki/Beer" title="Beer">beer</a> lover".<sup id="cite_ref-483" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-483"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>480<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Public_image">Public image</h2></div>
<p>It is hard to gauge the opinion of the Chinese public on Xi, as no independent surveys exist in China and social media is heavily censored.<sup id="cite_ref-484" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-484"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>481<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> However, he is believed to be widely popular in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-485" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-485"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>482<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-486" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-486"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>483<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> According to a 2014 poll co-sponsored by the <a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_School_of_Government" class="mw-redirect" title="John F. Kennedy School of Government">Harvard Kennedy School's</a> <a href="/wiki/Ash_Center_for_Democratic_Governance_and_Innovation" title="Ash Center for Democratic Governance and Innovation">Ash Center for Democratic Governance and Innovation</a>, Xi ranked 9 out of 10 in domestic approval ratings.<sup id="cite_ref-487" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-487"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>484<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/YouGov" title="YouGov">YouGov</a> poll released in July 2019 found that about 22% of people in mainland China list Xi as the person they admire the most, a plurality, although this figure was less than 5% for residents of Hong Kong.<sup id="cite_ref-488" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-488"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>485<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In the spring of 2019, the Pew Research Center made a survey on confidence on Xi Jinping among six-country medians based on Australia, India, Indonesia, Japan, Philippines and South Korea, which indicated that a median 29% have confidence in Xi Jinping to do the right thing regarding world affairs, meanwhile a median of 45% have no confidence; these numbers are slightly higher than those of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un (23% confidence, 53% no confidence).<sup id="cite_ref-489" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-489"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>486<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> A poll by <a href="/wiki/Politico" title="Politico">Politico</a> and <a href="/wiki/Morning_Consult" title="Morning Consult">Morning Consult</a> in 2021 found that 5% of Americans have a favorable opinion of Xi, 38% unfavorable, 17% no opinion and 40%, a plurality, never hearing of him.<sup id="cite_ref-490" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-490"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>487<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In 2017, <i>The Economist</i> named him the most powerful person in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-491" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-491"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>488<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2018, <i><a href="/wiki/Forbes" title="Forbes">Forbes</a></i> ranked him as <a href="/wiki/Forbes_list_of_the_World%27s_Most_Powerful_People" title="Forbes list of the World&#39;s Most Powerful People">the most powerful and influential person in the world</a>, replacing <a href="/wiki/President_of_Russia" title="President of Russia">Russian President</a> Vladimir Putin, who had been ranked so for five consecutive years.<sup id="cite_ref-492" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-492"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>489<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Since 2013, <a href="/wiki/Reporters_Without_Borders" title="Reporters Without Borders">Reporters Without Borders</a>, an international non-profit and non-governmental organization with the stated aim of safeguarding the right to freedom of information, included Xi among the list of <a href="/wiki/Press_freedom_predator" title="Press freedom predator">press freedom predators</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-493" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-493"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>490<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Selected_works">Selected works</h2></div>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Notes">Notes</h2></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1239543626">.mw-parser-output .reflist{margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}@media screen{.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%}}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist reflist-lower-alpha">
<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1177148991">.mw-parser-output .IPA-label-small{font-size:85%}.mw-parser-output .references .IPA-label-small,.mw-parser-output .infobox .IPA-label-small,.mw-parser-output .navbox .IPA-label-small{font-size:100%}</style><span class="IPA-label IPA-label-small">English: </span><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="/ʃ/: &#39;sh&#39; in &#39;shy&#39;">ʃ</span><span title="/iː/: &#39;ee&#39; in &#39;fleece&#39;">iː</span></span><span class="wrap"> </span><span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/dʒ/: &#39;j&#39; in &#39;jam&#39;">dʒ</span><span title="/ɪ/: &#39;i&#39; in &#39;kit&#39;">ɪ</span><span title="&#39;n&#39; in &#39;nigh&#39;">n</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="&#39;p&#39; in &#39;pie&#39;">p</span><span title="/ɪ/: &#39;i&#39; in &#39;kit&#39;">ɪ</span><span title="/ŋ/: &#39;ng&#39; in &#39;sing&#39;">ŋ</span></span>/</a></span></span> <a href="/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key" title="Help:Pronunciation respelling key"><i title="English pronunciation respelling"><span style="font-size:90%">SHEE</span> jin-<span style="font-size:90%">PING</span></i></a>, or often <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="/ʒ/: &#39;s&#39; <a href="/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters" title="Simplified Chinese characters">Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hans">习近平</span>; <a href="/wiki/Pinyin" title="Pinyin">pinyin</a>&#58; <i><span lang="zh-Latn">Xí Jìnpíng</span></i>, pronounced <span class="IPA" lang="cmn-Latn-fonipa" style="white-space:nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Mandarin" title="Help:IPA/Mandarin">[ɕi&#780;&#160;tɕi&#770;n.pʰi&#780;ŋ]</a></span>&#32;<span class="ext-phonos"><span data-nosnippet="" id="ooui-php-1" class="noexcerpt ext-phonos-PhonosButton ext-phonos-PhonosButton-emptylabel oo-ui-widget oo-ui-widget-enabled oo-ui-buttonElement oo-ui-buttonElement-frameless oo-ui-iconElement oo-ui-buttonWidget" data-ooui="{&quot;_&quot;:&quot;mw.Phonos.PhonosButton&quot;,&quot;href&quot;:&quot;\/\/upload.wikimedia.org\/wikipedia\/commons\/transcoded\/3\/33\/Xi_Jinping.ogg\/Xi_Jinping.ogg.mp3&quot;,&quot;rel&quot;:[&quot;nofollow&quot;],&quot;framed&quot;:false,&quot;icon&quot;:&quot;volumeUp&quot;,&quot;data&quot;:{&quot;ipa&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;text&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;lang&quot;:&quot;en&quot;,&quot;wikibase&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;file&quot;:&quot;Xi Jinping.ogg&quot;},&quot;classes&quot;:[&quot;noexcerpt&quot;,&quot;ext-phonos-PhonosButton&quot;,&quot;ext-phonos-PhonosButton-emptylabel&quot;]}"><a role="button" tabindex="0" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/3/33/Xi_Jinping.ogg/Xi_Jinping.ogg.mp3" rel="nofollow" aria-label="Play audio" title="Play audio" class="oo-ui-buttonElement-button"><span class="oo-ui-iconElement-icon oo-ui-icon-volumeUp"></span><span class="oo-ui-labelElement-label"></span><span class="oo-ui-indicatorElement-indicator oo-ui-indicatorElement-noIndicator"></span></a></span><sup class="ext-phonos-attribution noexcerpt navigation-not-searchable"><a href="/wiki/File:Xi_Jinping.ogg" title="File:Xi Jinping.ogg">ⓘ</a></sup></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-92"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-92">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Original <a href="/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters" title="Simplified Chinese characters">simplified Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hans">在国际金融风暴中, 中国能基本解决13亿人口吃饭的问题, 已经是对全人类最伟大的贡献</span>; <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters" title="Traditional Chinese characters">traditional Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hant">在國際金融風暴中, 中國能基本解決13億人口吃飯的問題, 已經是對全人類最偉大的貢獻</span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-93"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-93">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Original: <a href="/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters" title="Simplified Chinese characters">simplified Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hans">有些吃饱没事干的外国人, 对我们的事情指手画脚.中国一不输出革命, 二不输出饥饿和贫困, 三不折腾你们, 还有什么好说的?</span>; <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters" title="Traditional Chinese characters">traditional Chinese</a>&#58; <span lang="zh-Hant">有些吃飽沒事干的外國人, 對我們的事情指手畫腳.中國一不輸出革命, 二不輸出飢餓和貧困, 三不折騰你們, 還有什麽好說的?</span></span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>

<li id="cite_note-g605-15"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-g605_15-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFShi2017" class="citation book cs1 cs1-prop-script cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source">Shi, Z. C. (2017). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=MKSRswEACAAJ"><bdi lang="zh">习近平的七年知青岁月</bdi></a> &#91;<i>Xi Jinping's Seven Years as an Educated Youth</i>&#93; (in Chinese). <li id="cite_note-p946-52"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-p946_52-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite class="citation news cs1 cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.singtao.ca/6452821/2023-11-16/news-104%E6%AD%B2%E4%B8%AD%E5%85%B1%E5%85%83%E8%80%81%E4%BD%95%E8%BC%89%E9%80%9D%E4%B8%96++%E6%9B%BE%E8%96%A6%E7%BF%92%E8%BF%91%E5%B9%B3%E3%80%8C%E6%A3%9F%E6%A8%91%E4%B9%8B%E6%89%8D%E3%80%8D/?variant=zh-cn&amp;appedition=toronto">"104岁中共元老何载逝世 曾荐习近平"栋梁之才"<span class="cs1-kern-right"></span>"</a> &#91;He Zai, a 104-year-old CCP veteran, passed away. <li id="cite_note-76"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-76">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite class="citation news cs1 cs1-prop-script cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.boxun.com/news/gb/china/2013/07/201307110449.shtml#.VTxXVvnF_tU"><bdi lang="zh">从上海到北京 习近平贴身秘书只有钟绍军</bdi></a> &#91;From Shanghai to Beijing, Zhong Shaojun Has Been Xi Jinping's Only Personal Secretary&#93;. <i><a href="/wiki/Mingjing_News" title="Mingjing News">Mingjing News</a></i> (in Simplified Chinese). 11 July 2013. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20180612141343/http://www.boxun.com/news/gb/china/2013/07/201307110449.shtml#.VTxXVvnF_tU">Archived</a> from the original on 12 June 2018<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-188"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-188">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/WEO/weo-database/2023/April">"World Economic Outlook Database, April 2023"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a></i>. <li id="cite_note-229"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-229">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFWee2021" class="citation news cs1">Wee, Sui-Lee (31 May 2021). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/05/31/world/asia/china-three-child-policy.html">"China Says It Will Allow Couples to Have 3 Children, Up From 2"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i>. <a href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://search.worldcat.org/issn/0362-4331">0362-4331</a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20211104064050/https://www.nytimes.com/2021/05/31/world/asia/china-three-child-policy.html">Archived</a> from the original on 4 November 2021<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-369"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-369">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFChin2021" class="citation news cs1">Chin, Josh (30 November 2021). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/leaked-documents-detail-xi-jinpings-extensive-role-in-xinjiang-crackdown-11638284709">"Leaked Documents Detail Xi Jinping's Extensive Role in Xinjiang Crackdown"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal" title="The Wall Street Journal">The Wall Street Journal</a></i>. <a href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://search.worldcat.org/issn/0099-9660">0099-9660</a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20220812142807/https://www.wsj.com/articles/leaked-documents-detail-xi-jinpings-extensive-role-in-xinjiang-crackdown-11638284709">Archived</a> from the original on 12 August 2022<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-370"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-370">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite class="citation cs2"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Se2h1pyAjKw"><i>Momen Langka! Presiden China Xi Jinping Kunjungi Kampung Muslim Uighur</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/Kompas_TV" title="Kompas TV">Kompas TV</a>, 19 July 2022, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20240307204442/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Se2h1pyAjKw">archived</a> from the original on 7 March 2024<span class="reference-accessdate">, retrieved <span class="nowrap">7 March</span> 2024</span> &#8211; via Youtube, <q>Selama 4 hari, Xi Jinping mengunjungi sejumlah situs di Xinjiang termasuk perkebunan kapas, zona perdagangan dan museum. Penduduk Uighur pun menyambut Presiden Xi Jinping. Dalam kunjungannya, Xi mendesak agar pejabat Xinjiang selalu mendengarkan suara rakyat demi memenangkan hati dan membuat rakyat bersatu.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Momen+Langka%21+Presiden+China+Xi+Jinping+Kunjungi+Kampung+Muslim+Uighur&amp;rft.pub=Kompas+TV&amp;rft.date=2022-07-19&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.youtube.com%2Fwatch%3Fv%3DSe2h1pyAjKw&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AXi+Jinping" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-371"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-371">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite class="citation cs2"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=s0Q2iq_HVFs&amp;t=42s"><i>China's President Xi visits far western Xinjiang region for first time in 8 years</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/SCMP" class="mw-redirect" title="SCMP">SCMP</a>, 15 July 2022, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20240307204440/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=s0Q2iq_HVFs&amp;t=42s">archived</a> from the original on 7 March 2024<span class="reference-accessdate">, retrieved <span class="nowrap">7 March</span> 2024</span> &#8211; via Youtube</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=China%27s+President+Xi+visits+far+western+Xinjiang+region+for+first+time+in+8+years&amp;rft.pub=SCMP&amp;rft.date=2022-07-15&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.youtube.com%2Fwatch%3Fv%3Ds0Q2iq_HVFs%26t%3D42s&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AXi+Jinping" class="Z3988"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-372"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-372">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.dw.com/en/china-xi-jinping-visits-xinjiang-for-first-time-since-uyghur-crackdown/a-62481343">"Xi Jinping visits Xinjiang for first time since crackdown"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Deutsche_Welle" title="Deutsche Welle">Deutsche Welle</a></i>. 15 July 2022.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Deutsche+Welle&amp;rft.atitle=Xi+Jinping+visits+Xinjiang+for+first+time+since+crackdown&amp;rft.date=2022-07-15&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.dw.com%2Fen%2Fchina-xi-jinping-visits-xinjiang-for-first-time-since-uyghur-crackdown%2Fa-62481343&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AXi+Jinping" class="Z3988"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-373"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-373">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFONG_HAN_SEAN2023" class="citation web cs1">ONG HAN SEAN (20 November 2023). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.thestar.com.my/lifestyle/travel/2023/11/20/xinjiang-is-a-land-that039s-full-of-culture-colour-and-charm">"China's Xinjiang: A marvel of wild beauty and a land full of culture and charm"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_Star_(Malaysia)" title="The Star (Malaysia)">The Star</a></i>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20231120143603/https://www.thestar.com.my/lifestyle/travel/2023/11/20/xinjiang-is-a-land-that039s-full-of-culture-colour-and-charm">Archived</a> from the original on 20 November 2023. <q>Our visit came on the heels of Chinese President Xi Jinping's visit to Ürümqi, where he reportedly stressed on the positive promotion of the region to show an open and confident Xinjiang. Xi also called for Xinjiang to be opened more widely for tourism to encourage visits from domestic and foreign tourists.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Star&amp;rft.atitle=China%27s+Xinjiang%3A+A+marvel+of+wild+beauty+and+a+land+full+of+culture+and+charm&amp;rft.date=2023-11-20&amp;rft.au=ONG+HAN+SEAN&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.thestar.com.my%2Flifestyle%2Ftravel%2F2023%2F11%2F20%2Fxinjiang-is-a-land-that039s-full-of-culture-colour-and-charm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AXi+Jinping" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-374"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-374">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.dw.com/en/china-how-is-beijing-whitewashing-its-xinjiang-policy/a-66779242">"China: How is Beijing whitewashing its Xinjiang policy?"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Deutsche_Welle" title="Deutsche Welle">Deutsche Welle</a></i>. 11 September 2023. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20240307204440/https://www.dw.com/en/china-how-is-beijing-whitewashing-its-xinjiang-policy/a-66779242">Archived</a> from the original on 7 March 2024<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">7 March</span> 2024</span>. <q>But amid growing global attention on Xinjiang, China has been eager to portray the region as a "success story" by welcoming more tourists. In a speech that he made while visiting the region last month, Xi said Xinjiang was "no longer a remote area" and should open up more to domestic and foreign tourism.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Deutsche+Welle&amp;rft.atitle=China%3A+How+is+Beijing+whitewashing+its+Xinjiang+policy%3F&amp;rft.date=2023-09-11&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.dw.com%2Fen%2Fchina-how-is-beijing-whitewashing-its-xinjiang-policy%2Fa-66779242&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AXi+Jinping" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-383"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-383">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFDavidson2022" class="citation web cs1">Davidson, Helen (10 June 2022). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jun/10/xi-jinping-says-persistence-is-victory-as-covid-restrictions-return-to-shanghai-and-beijing">"Xi Jinping says 'persistence is victory' as Covid restrictions return to Shanghai and Beijing"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">The Guardian</a></i>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20240711082026/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jun/10/xi-jinping-says-persistence-is-victory-as-covid-restrictions-return-to-shanghai-and-beijing">Archived</a> from the original on 11 July 2024<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-427"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-427">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite class="citation news cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.economist.com/china/2017/08/17/the-communist-party-is-redefining-what-it-means-to-be-chinese">"The Communist Party is redefining what it means to be Chinese"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_Economist" title="The Economist">The Economist</a></i>. 17 August 2017<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-443"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-443">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFBrady2015" class="citation journal cs1">Brady, Anne-Marie (2015). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://muse.jhu.edu/content/crossref/journals/journal_of_democracy/v026/26.4.brady.html">"China's Foreign Propaganda Machine"</a>. <i>Journal of Democracy</i>. <b>26</b> (4): <span class="nowrap">51–</span>59. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1353%2Fjod.2015.0056">10.1353/jod.2015.0056</a>. <a href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://search.worldcat.org/issn/1086-3214">1086-3214</a>. <a href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:146531927">146531927</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Democracy&amp;rft.atitle=China%27s+Foreign+Propaganda+Machine&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.pages=51-59&amp;rft.date=2015&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A146531927%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft.issn=1086-3214&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1353%2Fjod.2015.0056&amp;rft.aulast=Brady&amp;rft.aufirst=Anne-Marie&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fmuse.jhu.edu%2Fcontent%2Fcrossref%2Fjournals%2Fjournal_of_democracy%2Fv026%2F26.4.brady.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AXi+Jinping" class="Z3988"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-477"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-477">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.usfq.edu.ec/sites/default/files/inline-files/a-look-at-whats-on-chinese-president-xi-jinpings-shelves.pdf">"A look at what's on Chinese President Xi Jinping's shelves"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i><a href="/wiki/Universidad_San_Francisco_de_Quito" title="Universidad San Francisco de Quito">Universidad San Francisco de Quito</a></i>. <q>Xi Jinping talks about Western literature [...] "Dostoevsky is the deepest Russian writer, while Tolstoy is the widest. </li>
<li id="cite_note-485"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-485">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite id="CITEREFPhillips2017" class="citation news cs1">Phillips, Tom (14 October 2017). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/oct/14/xi-jinping-crushes-dissent-but-making-china-great-again">"Chairman Xi crushes dissent but poor believe he's making China great"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">The Guardian</a></i>. <a href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://search.worldcat.org/issn/0029-7712">0029-7712</a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20190826122356/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/oct/14/xi-jinping-crushes-dissent-but-making-china-great-again">Archived</a> from the original on 26 August 2019<span class="reference-accessdate">. Brookings Institution Press. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8157-2694-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8157-2694-4"><bdi>978-0-8157-2694-4</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Chinese+Politics+in+the+Xi+Jinping+Era%3A+Reassessing+Collective+Leadership&amp;rft.pub=Brookings+Institution+Press&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8157-2694-4&amp;rft.aulast=Li&amp;rft.aufirst=Cheng&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D3NKACwAAQBAJ&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AXi+Jinping" class="Z3988"></span></li>
<li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite class="citation journal cs1">Mulvad, Andreas Møller (2019). "Xiism as a hegemonic project in the making: Sino-communist ideology and the political economy of China's rise". <i>Review of International Studies</i>. <b>45</b> (3): <span class="nowrap">449–</span>470. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1017%2FS0260210518000530">10.1017/S0260210518000530</a>. <a href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:150473371">150473371</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Review+of+International+Studies&amp;rft.atitle=Xiism+as+a+hegemonic+project+in+the+making%3A+Sino-communist+ideology+and+the+political+economy+of+China%27s+rise&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.pages=449-470&amp;rft.date=2019&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1017%2FS0260210518000530&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A150473371%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft.aulast=Mulvad&amp;rft.aufirst=Andreas+M%C3%B8ller&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AXi+Jinping" class="Z3988"></span></li>
<li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite class="citation news cs1"><a href="/wiki/Evan_Osnos" title="Evan Osnos">Osnos, Evan</a> (14 February 2012). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/evanosnos/2012/02/chinas-valentines-day-in-washington.html">"China's Valentine's Day in Washington"</a>. <i>The New Yorker</i>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+New+Yorker&amp;rft.atitle=China%27s+Valentine%27s+Day+in+Washington&amp;rft.date=2012-02-14&amp;rft.aulast=Osnos&amp;rft.aufirst=Evan&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fonline%2Fblogs%2Fevanosnos%2F2012%2F02%2Fchinas-valentines-day-in-washington.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AXi+Jinping" class="Z3988"></span> Review of comment accompanying Xi's visit.</li>
<li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite class="citation news cs1"><a href="/wiki/Evan_Osnos" title="Evan Osnos">Osnos, Evan</a> (30 March 2015). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2015/04/06/born-red">"Born Red: How Xi Jinping, an unremarkable provincial administrator, became China's most authoritarian leader since Mao"</a>. <i>The New Yorker</i>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+New+Yorker&amp;rft.atitle=Born+Red%3A+How+Xi+Jinping%2C+an+unremarkable+provincial+administrator%2C+became+China%27s+most+authoritarian+leader+since+Mao&amp;rft.date=2015-03-30&amp;rft.aulast=Osnos&amp;rft.aufirst=Evan&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fmagazine%2F2015%2F04%2F06%2Fborn-red&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AXi+Jinping" class="Z3988"></span> Describes Xi Jinping's life.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Evan_Osnos" title="Evan Osnos">Osnos, Evan</a>, "China's Age of Malaise: Facing a grim economy, disillusioned youth, and fleeing entrepreneurs, Xi Jinping turns to the past," <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_Yorker" title="The New Yorker">The New Yorker</a></i>, 30 October 2023, pp.&#160;34–45. "Xi [...] has abandoned Deng [Xiaoping]'s 'courageous experiments' and ushered [China] into a straitened new age." (p.&#160;34.) "Year by year, Xi appears more at home in the world of the man he calls his 'best and closest friend,' <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a>." (p.&#160;36.) "Can Xi's China still manage the pairing of <a href="/wiki/Autocracy" title="Autocracy">autocracy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Capitalism" title="Capitalism">capitalism</a>?" (p.&#160;37.) "At his core, a longtime observer told me, Xi is 'Mao with money.'" (p.&#160;38.) "Xi [has] got[ten] rid of anyone with power, [an] entrepreneur said: 'If you have influence, you have power. If you have capital, you have power.'" (p.&#160;40.)</li>
<li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite class="citation journal cs1">Smith, Stephen N. (2021). "Harmonizing the periphery: China's neighborhood strategy under Xi Jinping". <i>Pacific Review</i>. <b>34</b> (1): <span class="nowrap">56–</span>84. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1080%2F09512748.2019.1651383">10.1080/09512748.2019.1651383</a>. <a href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:202329851">202329851</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Pacific+Review&amp;rft.atitle=Harmonizing+the+periphery%3A+China%27s+neighborhood+strategy+under+Xi+Jinping&amp;rft.volume=34&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.pages=56-84&amp;rft.date=2021&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1080%2F09512748.2019.1651383&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A202329851%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft.aulast=Smith&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephen+N.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AXi+Jinping" class="Z3988"></span></li>
<li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite class="citation journal cs1">Vogel, Ezra (2021). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1080%2F10670564.2021.1884955">"The Leadership of Xi Jinping: A Dengist Perspective"</a>. <i>Journal of Contemporary China</i>. <b>30</b> (131): <span class="nowrap">693–</span>696. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<span class="id-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1080%2F10670564.2021.1884955">10.1080/10670564.2021.1884955</a></span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Contemporary+China&amp;rft.atitle=The+Leadership+of+Xi+Jinping%3A+A+Dengist+Perspective&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=131&amp;rft.pages=693-696&amp;rft.date=2021&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1080%2F10670564.2021.1884955&amp;rft.aulast=Vogel&amp;rft.aufirst=Ezra&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fdoi.org%2F10.1080%252F10670564.2021.1884955&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AXi+Jinping" class="Z3988"></span></li>
<li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222" /><cite class="citation journal cs1">Zhang, Feng (2019). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20190904061419/https://www.questia.com/library/journal/1P4-2275866529/the-xi-jinping-doctrine-of-china-s-international-relations">"The Xi Jinping Doctrine of China's International Relations"</a>. <i>Asia Policy</i>. <b>14</b> (3). Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.questia.com/library/journal/1P4-2275866529/the-xi-jinping-doctrine-of-china-s-international-relations">the original</a> on 4 September 2019<span class="reference-accessdate">. <ul><li><a href="/wiki/General_secretaryship_of_Xi_Jinping" title="General secretaryship of Xi Jinping">General secretaryship</a>

<td style="width: 40%; text-align: center;" rowspan="1"><b> <a href="/wiki/Governor_of_Zhejiang" title="Governor of Zhejiang">Governor of Zhejiang</a> </b><br />2002–2003
</td>
<td style="width: 30%; text-align: center;" rowspan="1">Succeeded&#160;by<div style="font-weight: bold"><a href="/wiki/L%C3%BC_Zushan" title="Lü Zushan">Lü Zushan</a></div>
</td></tr>


<tr style="text-align:center;">

</td>
<td style="width: 30%; text-align: center;" rowspan="1">Succeeded&#160;by<div style="font-weight: bold"><a href="/wiki/Yu_Guoxing" title="Yu Guoxing">Yu Guoxing</a></div>
</td></tr>


<tr style="text-align:center;">

<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Chen_Duxiu" title="Chen Duxiu">Chen Duxiu</a> (1921–1927)</li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Zhang_Wentian" title="Zhang Wentian">Zhang Wentian</a> (1935–1943)</li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Hua_Guofeng" title="Hua Guofeng">Hua Guofeng</a> (1976–1981)</li>

</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%;background: #be0c00; color: white;"><span style="color: white">Decision-making bodies</span></th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-even" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">

</div></td></tr></tbody></table><div></div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%;background: #be0c00; color: white;"><span style="color: white">Approved by the<br />Central Committee</span></th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em"></div><table class="nowraplinks hlist navbox-subgroup" style="border-spacing:0"><tbody><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%;background: #be0c00; color: white;"><a href="/wiki/Secretariat_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Secretariat of the Chinese Communist Party"><span style="color: white">Secretariat</span></a></th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">

				</div>
			</main>
